When would I use the Inbox? Use the Inbox to: Send a message to someone in your course or group Send a message to yourself (displays in your Sent folder) Reply to messages from others in your course Filter conversations by course or type View and reply to assignment submission comments Learn more about using the Inbox . Note: You can adjust your notification settings to receive messages using external channels.

input: How can I set up score-based conditional pages or assignments with different score ranges in Canvas Modules Mastery Paths?
expected_output:
1. Enable Mastery Paths in your course  
   - Go to Settings > Feature Options  
   - Turn on “Mastery Paths”  

2. Prepare your content  
   - Create or add your source item (graded assignment, quiz, or discussion) in a module  
   - Create all conditional pages or assignments and add them to the same module (they can be unpublished or hidden until released)  

3. Add a Mastery Path to your source item  
   - In Modules, locate your source item  
   - Click the three-dot menu next to it and choose “Add Mastery Paths”  

4. Define your score ranges  
   - In the Mastery Paths pane, click + Add Range for each interval you need (for example 0–59%, 60–89%, 90–100%)  
   - Enter the minimum and maximum percentages for that range  

5. Assign conditional content to each range  
   - Under each score range, click + Add to select the pages or assignments that students should receive  
   - (Only graded assignments/discussions/quizzes, pages, links, and files embedded in pages or assignments can be used)  

6. Save and publish  
   - Click Save  
   - Publish your module items  

Result for students: After their source item is graded, Canvas automatically unlocks and displays only the pages or assignments matching their earned score range.
context:
Document Title: What are Mastery Paths

What are Mastery Paths? Mastery Paths allows instructors to configure differentiated learning content that is automatically delivered to students based on their individual source assignment scores. Any graded assignment, graded discussion, or graded quiz may be used as the source content for a Mastery Path. After the source assignment is graded (either manually or automatically), Mastery Paths releases conditional content to students based on scoring-range rules. A student's score determines their assigned learning path. For instance, a student who scores above 90% on an assignment could be assigned more advanced work, while a student who scores below 60% could view assignments designed for content clarification and improvement. Any course item except for practice quizzes, ungraded surveys, and external tool assignments may be designated as a conditional item in a Mastery Path. Course items such as links, files, and media content must be embedded in a page or assignment to be used as conditional content in Mastery Paths. Notes: The Mastery Paths setting can be managed in a course if the setting has been enabled by an institution . If your institution uses a student information system (SIS) and requires due dates for assignments, any Mastery Path assignment assigned to one or more students are currently not validated. Please use this with caution when syncing to an SIS. If a course has a large number of students and/or if a Mastery Path has a large number of associated conditional items, students may experience a delay before they are assigned a path. Currently, Mastery Paths does not support association with outcomes. Files, External URLs, and External Tool module items cannot be used as conditional items in Mastery Paths. Mastery Paths pages are only accessible to students from within Mastery Paths and not in the course Pages page.  Instructor View Instructors create and manage Mastery Paths in the course Modules page. Any graded assignment, graded discussion, or graded quiz may be used as the source content for a Mastery Path. A student's source content score determines their next assignment(s). Note: Before building Mastery Paths in the Modules page, instructors should create or add all course assignments, activities, and pages, and then add them in modules. Learn more about creating Mastery Paths in course modules . Source Content Learning Paths For each source assignment, instructors add conditional content within scoring ranges. Conditional items and requirements can vary for each scoring range. Note: To differentiate an assignment for students based on scoring ranges, instructors must also assign conditional content items to Mastery Paths . Mastery Paths Breakdowns Once students complete source assignments, instructors can view Mastery Paths range breakdowns that show the number of students who scored in each range. Student View When students view course modules in a Mastery Path course, they may see that module items are restricted until source assignments are graded. When unlocked, students may be able to choose their learning path assignments .

input: How can I configure Mastery Paths in Canvas to automatically release assignments based on students’ quiz score ranges?
expected_output:
1. Enable Mastery Paths in your course  
   - Go to Course Settings > Feature Options and turn on Mastery Paths.  

2. Prepare your content  
   - Create or add all graded quizzes, assignments, pages, and activities you’ll use in your paths.  
   - Embed any files, links, or media in pages or assignments (external-tool items can’t be conditional).  

3. Add the source quiz to a module  
   - In Modules, click “+” and add your graded quiz (this becomes the source assignment).  

4. Configure the Mastery Path  
   - In the module, click the three-dot menu next to the quiz and select Add Mastery Path.  
   - In the Mastery Paths sidebar, define your score ranges (e.g., 90–100%, 60–89%, 0–59%).  

5. Assign conditional content for each range  
   - Under each score bracket, click Add Content.  
   - Select pages, assignments, discussions, or quizzes to release when students fall into that range.  

6. Publish and test  
   - Publish your modules and conditional items.  
   - After students complete the quiz, Canvas will automatically unlock the content matching their score range.
context:
Document Title: What are Mastery Paths

What are Mastery Paths? Mastery Paths allows instructors to configure differentiated learning content that is automatically delivered to students based on their individual source assignment scores. Any graded assignment, graded discussion, or graded quiz may be used as the source content for a Mastery Path. After the source assignment is graded (either manually or automatically), Mastery Paths releases conditional content to students based on scoring-range rules. A student's score determines their assigned learning path. For instance, a student who scores above 90% on an assignment could be assigned more advanced work, while a student who scores below 60% could view assignments designed for content clarification and improvement. Any course item except for practice quizzes, ungraded surveys, and external tool assignments may be designated as a conditional item in a Mastery Path. Course items such as links, files, and media content must be embedded in a page or assignment to be used as conditional content in Mastery Paths. Notes: The Mastery Paths setting can be managed in a course if the setting has been enabled by an institution . If your institution uses a student information system (SIS) and requires due dates for assignments, any Mastery Path assignment assigned to one or more students are currently not validated. Please use this with caution when syncing to an SIS. If a course has a large number of students and/or if a Mastery Path has a large number of associated conditional items, students may experience a delay before they are assigned a path. Currently, Mastery Paths does not support association with outcomes. Files, External URLs, and External Tool module items cannot be used as conditional items in Mastery Paths. Mastery Paths pages are only accessible to students from within Mastery Paths and not in the course Pages page.  Instructor View Instructors create and manage Mastery Paths in the course Modules page. Any graded assignment, graded discussion, or graded quiz may be used as the source content for a Mastery Path. A student's source content score determines their next assignment(s). Note: Before building Mastery Paths in the Modules page, instructors should create or add all course assignments, activities, and pages, and then add them in modules. Learn more about creating Mastery Paths in course modules . Source Content Learning Paths For each source assignment, instructors add conditional content within scoring ranges. Conditional items and requirements can vary for each scoring range. Note: To differentiate an assignment for students based on scoring ranges, instructors must also assign conditional content items to Mastery Paths . Mastery Paths Breakdowns Once students complete source assignments, instructors can view Mastery Paths range breakdowns that show the number of students who scored in each range. Student View When students view course modules in a Mastery Path course, they may see that module items are restricted until source assignments are graded. When unlocked, students may be able to choose their learning path assignments .

input: How can instructors structure weekly Canvas Modules, include varied items, set prerequisites, and monitor completion?
expected_output:
1. Create Weekly Modules  
   a. Go to your course Modules page.  
   b. Click the “+ Module” button, name it “Week 1,” “Week 2,” etc., and click Add Module.  

2. Add Varied Content  
   a. In each module, click the “+” icon.  
   b. From the dropdown select the content type you need (File, Page, Assignment, Quiz, Discussion, External Tool).  
   c. Search or create new content, then click Add Item.  
   d. Drag and drop items to reorder or nest under headings.  

3. Set Prerequisites and Requirements  
   a. Click the module’s three-dot menu and choose “Edit.”  
   b. Under Requirements, click “+ Add” to:  
      • Require completion of a specific item before students proceed.  
      • Lock the module until the previous module is complete.  
   c. Save your settings.  

4. Monitor Student Completion  
   a. On the Modules page, published items display checkboxes that turn green when students meet requirements.  
   b. Click a student’s name on the People page to view their module progress.  
   c. Use Course Analytics (in the course menu) or the Student Interaction Report to track overall completion rates.
context:
Document Title: What are Modules

What are Modules? Modules allow instructors to organize content to help control the flow of the course. Modules are used to organize course content by weeks, units, or a different organizational structure. Modules essentially create a one-directional linear flow of what students should do in a course. Each module can contain files, discussions, assignments, quizzes, and other learning materials. Module items can be added to the course from existing content or new content shells within the modules. Course content can be added to multiple modules or iterated several times throughout an individual module. Modules can be easily organized using the drag and drop feature. Elements within the modules can also be reorganized by dragging and dropping. Note: Keyboard shortcuts can be used to navigate the Modules page. To view a window with a list of keyboard navigation shortcuts, press the Shift+Question Mark keys simultaneously on your keyboard.  Instructor View Instructors can add all course materials in modules, even if they are assigned to specific students, sections, or groups. Use Modules to: Create prerequisite activities that students must complete before moving on in the course Track student progress through a sequence of learning activities Organize course content by unit, day, week, topic or outcome Student View Students only view module content that has been published and assigned to them. Each module can contain files, discussions, assignments, quizzes, and other learning materials. Modules can be expanded and collapsed.

input: How do I add, reuse, or publish module items for specific sections or groups in Canvas, set prerequisites, and reorder items using drag-and-drop or keyboard shortcuts?
expected_output:
1. Go to your course’s Modules page.  
2. Add or reuse items:  
   a. Click the “+” icon on the right of a module header.  
   b. In the Add dialog, pick the item type (Page, Assignment, Quiz, etc.).  
   c. To reuse existing content, select it from the list; to create new, use the “New” option.  
   d. Click Add Item.  
3. Assign to sections or groups:  
   a. After adding, locate the module item row.  
   b. Click the gray Assign link (or gear icon) on the right.  
   c. In the Assign to field, choose specific sections or groups.  
   d. Click Done then Save.  
4. Set prerequisites:  
   a. For module-level prerequisites, click the three-dot menu next to the module title and choose Edit.  
   b. Under Module Requirements, check “Require students to complete prerequisites in order.”  
   c. Click + Add Requirement, pick the prerequisite item or module, and Save.  
5. Reorder items:  
   • Drag-and-drop: hover over the six-dot handle to the left of a module or item, then drag it to its new position.  
   • Keyboard shortcuts: press Shift + ? on the Modules page to view navigation and move-item shortcuts.

Each module can contain files, discussions, assignments, quizzes, and other learning materials. Module items can be added to the course from existing content or new content shells within the modules. Use Modules to: Create prerequisite activities that students must complete before moving on in the course Track student progress through a sequence of learning activities Organize course content by unit, day, week, topic or outcome Student View Students only view module content that has been published and assigned to them. Each module can contain files, discussions, assignments, quizzes, and other learning materials. Modules can be expanded and collapsed.

input: How do I align my quizzes and assignments to course outcomes in Canvas, choose one of the five mastery calculations, and generate the Learning Mastery Gradebook reports?
expected_output:
1. Create or edit your course outcomes with a mastery calculation  
   a. In Course Navigation, click “Outcomes.”  
   b. Click “+ Outcome” (or edit an existing outcome).  
   c. Enter a title and description.  
   d. Under “Calculation Method,” choose one of:  
      - Weighted Average (default 65/35 or custom ratio)  
      - Decaying Average (set decay rate 50–99%)  
      - n Number of Times (specify times 1–10)  
      - Most Recent Score  
      - Highest Score  
   e. Save your outcome.  

2. Align a quiz or assignment to your outcome  
   a. Open the quiz or assignment and click “Edit.”  
   b. Scroll to the “Alignments” or “Outcomes” section.  
   c. Click “+ Align” (or “Find Outcome”), search for your course outcome, and select it.  
   d. If desired, attach a rubric that maps criterion levels to outcome mastery.  
   e. Save your quiz or assignment.  

3. View and report student mastery in the Learning Mastery Gradebook  
   a. In Course Navigation, select “Learning Mastery Gradebook.”  
   b. Use the dropdown to choose the outcome you set up.  
   c. Review student scores according to your calculation method.  
   d. To export or print, click the gear icon (⋯) and choose “Export CSV” or “Print.”  

4. (Optional) Run account-level outcome reports  
   a. As an admin, go to Account > Outcomes > Reports.  
   b. Select the desired outcomes and date range.  
   c. Click “Generate Report” to download mastery data for accreditation or instructional review.
context:
Document Title: What are Outcomes

What are Outcomes? Outcomes allow the administration and faculty to track mastery in a course. Users can import Account, State, and Common Core Standards into an account and course.  Account or Course Outcomes Outcomes enables the administration and faculty to track students’ progress as measured by pedagogical goals or desired outcomes. Assessments created to test student knowledge or to require students to demonstrate a specific skill resulting from a learning activity can be aligned to learning outcomes using rubrics (which can be used for grading simultaneously). Grading student work automatically collects and compiles data on student progress for the Outcomes. The data is available for reporting to support teaching improvement, identify at-risk students, and support the accreditation process. This unified, streamlined approach dramatically reduces the amount of work required to implement Learning Outcomes through the intelligent reuse of assessment workflows in the grading process. When would I use Outcomes? Use Outcomes to: Focus students' attention on the most important skills and activities in your course (find existing outcomes or create new ones) Align Quizzes and Assignments to different kinds of mastery Run reports at the account-level about student artifacts of learning mastery Assess student progress through calculation methods Track student progress on a learning outcome or overall in the Learning Mastery Gradebook Align accreditation or other core standards to programs of study, courses, or student assessments Calculation Methods When users create an outcome, users can set one of four calculation methods used for student mastery: Weighted Average, Decaying Average, n Number of Times, Most Recent Score, and Highest Score. Calculation methods are used in conjunction within the Learning Mastery Gradebook. Calculation methods can be set when creating custom course outcomes (instructors) or creating custom account outcomes (admins). Notes: For new Outcomes created in the Canvas interface, the default calculation is Weighted Average unless changed to another calculation. For new Outcomes created using the Outcomes API, the default calculation is set as Highest Score but can be modified with the appropriate parameters. If a user imports an outcome but does not have permission to modify the calculation method, the calculation method cannot be changed. Common Core outcomes are always calculated as Highest Score; however, the calculation method can be modified using the Outcomes API by any user with appropriate admin permissions. Weighted Average The Weighted Average calculation factors the average of all assessment items while weighing the most recent (current) submission to any assignment associated with this outcome at a higher percentage. By default, the Canvas weighted average is set at 65/35, meaning the current item is weighted at 65%, and the average of all other user scores is weighted at 35%. However, users can specify between 1% and 99% for the current percentage, and prior scores are weighted against the percentage difference. Note that the average is rounded to the next two decimals. If there is only one result, then the single score will be displayed. For example, a student has four aligned items with scores of 4, 3, 2, and 5 (scores listed chronologically from oldest to most recent). If the current item is set to be weighted at 65% of mastery, prior scores are weighted at 35%: Current item score: 5 Average of prior item scores: (4 + 3 + 2) / 3 = 3 Calculated score: 5 (.65) + 3 (.35) = 3.25 + 1.05 = 4.3 Decaying Average The Decaying Average calculation uses a formula to determine proficiency based on students' average scores, giving more weight to the most recent scored. To determine the weight given to the most recent score, the formula uses a decay rate. The higher the formula's decay rate, the more heavily the most recent assessment is weighted. By default, the decay weight is set at 65%. However, you can adjust the rate to any percentage between 50% and 99%. Between two assessments, the most recent assessment gets 65% weight and the first gets 35%. For each additional assessment, the sum of the|Document Title: What are Outcomes

can adjust the rate to any percentage between 50% and 99%. Between two assessments, the most recent assessment gets 65% weight and the first gets 35%. For each additional assessment, the sum of the previous score calculations decay by an additional 35%. For example, a student has scores of 1, 2, 3, 4 (scores listed chronologically from oldest to most recent): (1 × .35) + (2 × .65) = X (X × .35) + (3 × .65) = Y (Y × .35) + (4 × .65) = Z  (this being the current standard score; 3.48) n Number of Times The n Number of Times calculation requires a specific number of times that mastery must be met or exceeded, and the number of aligned items that must be completed for calculation eligibility. Any scores that do not meet mastery are not part of the calculation. Users can specify between 1 and 10 items required for mastery. For example, a student is required to achieve mastery 2 times with a mastery score of 5. If the student has scores of 1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 3, and 6, only the scores of 5 and 6 would be part of the calculation. Average score of eligible items: 5 + 6 = 11 Calculated score: 11 / 2 = 5.5 Most Recent Score The Most Recent Score calculation always selects the most recent score for all assessment items. Highest Score The Highest Score calculation always selects the highest score for all assessment items. Select Average To select the average score from all assessment items, select the Average option . You can view an example of the Average calculation in the Example section . Note: Average is not a good fit for most outcomes-based or mastery-based learning use cases because students may need time to reach mastery of an outcome and early poorer performance can bring down an average. Outcome Mastery Scales If the Account and Course Level Outcome Mastery Scales feature option is enabled for your account, you can set mastery scales for the entire account. Learn more about mastery scales in an account or in a course . Outcome Mastery Calculations If the Account and Course Level Outcome Mastery Scales feature option is enabled for your account, you can set mastery calculations for the entire account. Learn more about mastery calculations in an account or in a course . Improved Outcomes Management If the Account and Course Level Outcome Mastery Scales feature option and the Improved Outcomes Management feature option are enabled for your account, the Outcomes page displays an improved interface for viewing and managing outcomes. Learn more about the Improved Outcomes Management in an account or in a course .

input: How can I configure weighted assignment groups (default 65% exams/35% assignments), adjust late submission penalty rates, set notification preferences, and manage grading schemes through the Canvas UI or API?
expected_output:
1. Configure weighted assignment groups  
   • UI: In your course, go to Settings > Grading > enable Use weighted assignment groups > Save. Then open Assignments, click the gear icon by each group, set “Weight (%)” (e.g., Exams = 65, Assignments = 35), and Update.  
   • API: PUT /api/v1/courses/:course_id/assignment_groups/:group_id with JSON { “assignment_group”: { “group_weight”:65 } } (repeat for each group).  

2. Adjust late submission penalty rates  
   • UI: Course Settings > Submission Policies (or Account Settings > Policies) > Edit Late Submission Policy > specify deduction rate (%) and grace period > Save. You can also set per-assignment under each assignment’s Settings > Late Policies.  
   • API: PUT /api/v1/courses/:course_id/assignments/:assignment_id with “late_policy” object, for example:  
     { “assignment”: { “late_policy”: { “missing_submission_deduction_enabled”:true, “late_submission_deduction”:“10” } } }  

3. Set notification preferences  
   • UI: Click the Account icon (top left) > Notifications > for each event (e.g., Submission Comment), choose notification frequency (right-hand column). Selections save automatically.  
   • API: PUT /api/v1/users/:user_id/communication_channels/:id or /api/v1/users/:user_id/notification_preferences with appropriate “notification_type” and “notification_level.”  

4. Manage grading schemes  
   • UI: Course Settings > scroll to Grading Scheme > click + View/Edit Grading Scheme > add or modify letter/percentage ranges > Update Grading Scheme.  
   • API: GET/PUT /api/v1/courses/:course_id/grading_standards with JSON { “grading_standard”: { “title”:“Custom Scheme”, “grading_scheme_entries”:[{“name”:“A”,“value”:93},…] } }.

input: How do I use the instructor-only Options icon to set a page as the course front page?
expected_output:
1. In your course navigation, open Pages.  
2. Click the title of the page you want as your front page.  
3. In the page header, click the Options (gear) icon.  
4. Select Use as Front Page. The selected page now displays as your course’s front page.
context:
Document Title: What are Pages

What are Pages? Pages store content and educational resources that are part of a course or group but don’t necessarily belong in an assignment. Pages can include text, video, and links to files and other course or group content. Pages can also be linked to other pages. They can also be used as a collaboration tool for course or group wikis where only specific users can have access. Canvas keeps the entire history of the page to account for changes over time.  Instructor View In a course, instructors can create a new page with text, images, media, links, and/or other files . The Options icon allows instructors to edit the title of a page, delete a page, use it as the front page, duplicate the page, send a copy of the page to another instructor at their institution, or copy the page to one of their other courses . The Delete button allows instructors to delete selected pages . Student View Students can view pages in courses. However, instructors can allow students to edit and contribute to course pages. Students can always create pages in their student group. In groups, students can view the same page layout with the name of the page, creation dates, and edit dates. They can also add new pages in a group . In the Options icon, they can edit, delete, or use a page as the front page for a group . Students can use the Delete button to delete selected pages for a group .

input: How do I configure the Pages options in a Canvas course to grant students edit and contribute rights?
expected_output:
1. In your Canvas course, click Pages in the Course Navigation, then click View All Pages.  
2. Find the page you want students to edit, hover over it, and click the Options (⋮) icon.  
3. From the menu, select Allow Student Editing (or Collaborate depending on your institution’s Canvas version).  
4. Click Save (or Done) to apply the change.  

Students will now see an Edit button on that page and can contribute directly.

input: How can I enable assignment-level anonymous peer review in Canvas LMS, hiding reviewer and reviewee names?
expected_output:
1. In your course, go to Assignments and click + Assignment (or edit an existing assignment).  
2. Scroll to the Peer Reviews section.  
3. Check “Require Peer Reviews.”  
4. Select either “Automatically assign peer reviews” or “Manually assign peer reviews.”  
5. Check “Anonymous peer reviews” to hide both reviewer and reviewee names.  
6. (Optional) If you want names hidden in SpeedGrader as well, enable Anonymous Grading in the Grading section.  
7. Click Save or Save & Publish.  

Note: Once you save an anonymous peer review setting, you cannot toggle it off—you would need to delete and re‐create the peer review.
context:
Document Title: What are Peer Reviews

What are Peer Reviews?
A peer review assignment or discussion enables students to provide feedback on another student's submission. Peer reviews allow communication between students and can help students master the concepts of a course and learn from each other. Peer reviews can be assigned to show student names or display anonymously.
Note:
Students can only view peer review assignments or discussions after they have submitted their own work for the assignment or replied to the discussion themselves.
When Would I Use Peer Reviews?
Student peer review assignments and discussions can:
Help students develop critical thinking skills by evaluating and providing feedback on their peers' work.
Enhance understanding of the subject matter.
Improve communication skills.
Promote a collaborative learning environment.
Teach students to give and receive constructive criticism.
Instructors can
create a peer review assignment
or
create a peer review discussion
.
Perform Peer Reviews
After submitting their own work, students can
submit a peer review
[1]. The student whose work was reviewed can then
view their peer’s feedback
[2].
Anonymous Peer Reviews
As part of creating a peer review, the anonymous option allows you to hide the name of the student reviewer from the student with the submission. The reviewer cannot see the name of the assigned person whose work is to be reviewed, and the student who submitted the assignment cannot view names associated with any comments.
Creating an anonymous peer review can reduce bias, encourage honest feedback, promote fairness, minimize pressure, and focus on learning.
Notes:
Email notifications sent to students about peer reviews are anonymous. Student reviewers cannot view the name of the person whose work they are reviewing.
Once a peer review has been assigned, the viewing setting cannot be changed. For instance, a regular peer review cannot later be made anonymous—and appear anonymous—unless the peer review is deleted and re-assigned.
Canvas DocViewer does not support anonymous comments, so it cannot be used for annotated feedback on assignments with anonymous peer reviews.
When anonymous peer reviews are enabled, instructors and TAs can still view the names of student reviewers in SpeedGrader and in the student submission page. However, if
anonymous grading is enabled in SpeedGrader
, the names of both students will be hidden in SpeedGrader but not in the student submission page.

input: Which Canvas peer review settings block all reviewer/reviewee names across submissions, notifications, DocViewer, and SpeedGrader?
expected_output:
1. Enable Anonymous Peer Reviews when you create the assignment or discussion  
   - Hides reviewer/reviewee names in the student submission view and in all peer‐review notification emails.  
2. Enable Anonymous Grading in SpeedGrader  
   - Hides both student names in SpeedGrader.  
3. Note: Canvas DocViewer does **not** support anonymous comments  
   - There is no Canvas setting that hides names in DocViewer. To maintain anonymity, provide feedback outside DocViewer (e.g., as text comments).
context:
Document Title: What are Peer Reviews

What are Peer Reviews?
A peer review assignment or discussion enables students to provide feedback on another student's submission. Peer reviews allow communication between students and can help students master the concepts of a course and learn from each other. Peer reviews can be assigned to show student names or display anonymously.
Note:
Students can only view peer review assignments or discussions after they have submitted their own work for the assignment or replied to the discussion themselves.
When Would I Use Peer Reviews?
Student peer review assignments and discussions can:
Help students develop critical thinking skills by evaluating and providing feedback on their peers' work.
Enhance understanding of the subject matter.
Improve communication skills.
Promote a collaborative learning environment.
Teach students to give and receive constructive criticism.
Instructors can
create a peer review assignment
or
create a peer review discussion
.
Perform Peer Reviews
After submitting their own work, students can
submit a peer review
[1]. The student whose work was reviewed can then
view their peer’s feedback
[2].
Anonymous Peer Reviews
As part of creating a peer review, the anonymous option allows you to hide the name of the student reviewer from the student with the submission. The reviewer cannot see the name of the assigned person whose work is to be reviewed, and the student who submitted the assignment cannot view names associated with any comments.
Creating an anonymous peer review can reduce bias, encourage honest feedback, promote fairness, minimize pressure, and focus on learning.
Notes:
Email notifications sent to students about peer reviews are anonymous. Student reviewers cannot view the name of the person whose work they are reviewing.
Once a peer review has been assigned, the viewing setting cannot be changed. For instance, a regular peer review cannot later be made anonymous—and appear anonymous—unless the peer review is deleted and re-assigned.
Canvas DocViewer does not support anonymous comments, so it cannot be used for annotated feedback on assignments with anonymous peer reviews.
When anonymous peer reviews are enabled, instructors and TAs can still view the names of student reviewers in SpeedGrader and in the student submission page. However, if
anonymous grading is enabled in SpeedGrader
, the names of both students will be hidden in SpeedGrader but not in the student submission page.

input: How do I change my profile picture in Canvas LMS by going to Account > Profile > Edit Profile Picture, and what are the options for uploading from camera, uploading a file, or using Gravatar?
expected_output:
1. In Global Navigation, click Account > Profile.  
2. Click the Edit Profile Picture button.  
3. Choose one of three options:  
   • Upload a file – select an image from your computer.  
   • Take a picture – use your computer’s camera.  
   • Import from Gravatar – pull an existing Gravatar image.  
4. When you’ve selected or captured your picture, click Save.

2. On your Profile page, locate the Edit Profile button in the upper-right corner (to the right of your profile picture and name).  
3. Click Edit Profile to open the editable fields, including your Biography.

input: In the Canvas Admin UI, which click sequence opens account-level Question Banks under Account Navigation?
expected_output:
1. In the global Canvas navigation, click Admin.  
2. Select the desired account name.  
3. In the Account Navigation menu, click Question Banks.
context:
Document Title: What are question banks

What are question banks? You can create account and sub-account level Question Banks in your Canvas instance. This allows anyone in the account to have access to the questions.  Open Account To view Question Banks, click the Admin link , then click the name of the account . Open Question Banks In Account Navigation, click the Question Banks link. Account-level question banks are question banks created and stored at the account level. This allows users to access and use general content for quizzes. When Would I Use Account-Level Question Banks? Account-level questions banks can be used to create institutional or departmental question repositories. For example, if the English department offers several courses to teach basic grammar rules to students, the department can create a sub-account level question bank. Instructors can then access the question banks to offer the same evaluation to students in different courses.

input: What steps do I follow in Canvas to create a question bank at the department sub-account level?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, click Admin in the global navigation.  
2. Select your department’s sub-account from the list.  
3. In the sub-account navigation menu, click Question Banks.  
4. Click + Question Bank in the top right.  
5. Enter a name for your question bank and click Create Bank.

input: How do I import external questions, organize them into question banks, set up pagination, and assign graded quizzes to different course sections in Canvas?
expected_output:
1. Import external questions  
   a. In Course Navigation, click Quizzes, then + Quiz.  
   b. Under the quiz editor, select Import > QTI .zip or other supported format.  
   c. Upload your file and click Import. Imported questions appear in the quiz.

2. Organize questions into banks  
   a. In Course Navigation, go to Quizzes > Manage Question Banks.  
   b. Click + Question Bank, name it, and save.  
   c. From the quiz editor, select Questions > Find Questions > Question Banks.  
   d. Choose your bank and select questions to import into the quiz.

3. Set up pagination (one question per page)  
   a. In the quiz editor, scroll to Quiz Settings.  
   b. Enable “Show one question at a time.”  
   c. (Optional) Lock questions after answering and randomize order for security.

4. Assign graded quizzes to specific course sections  
   a. In the quiz editor, click the Assign tab.  
   b. Under “Assign to,” remove Everyone and click + Add .  
   c. Select a course section from the dropdown.  
   d. Set due date, availability, and points.  
   e. Repeat for each section as needed.  
   f. Click Save & Publish.
context:
Document Title: What are Quizzes

What are Quizzes? Quizzes in Canvas are assignments that can be used to challenge student understanding and assess comprehension of course material. The quiz tool is used to create and administer online quizzes and surveys. Quizzes can also be used to conduct and moderate exams and assessments, both graded and ungraded. Canvas has four different types of quizzes: A graded quiz is the most common quiz and rewards students points based on their quiz responses. A practice quiz is a learning tool to see how well users understand course material without providing a grade. A graded survey rewards students with points for completing a survey but grading is not based on right or wrong answers. An ungraded survey obtains opinions or other information without providing a grade. To know more about using New Quizzes, refer to the dedicated guides for instructors and students . To see a breakdown of how Classic Quizzes compares to New Quizzes, refer to the Classic Quizzes vs. New Quizzes Feature Comparison resource document.  When would I use Quizzes as an instructor? You can use Quizzes to: Create new quizzes with individual questions and question groups Set up question banks Import external quizzes Show one quiz question at a time Create quizzes for all students, individual students, or course sections When would I use Quizzes as a student? You can use Quizzes to: Test your knowledge of course material View all available quizzes in your course Submit quizzes in your course View quiz questions one at a time or all at once (depending on instructor preference) Review quiz results

input: How do Canvas students view available quizzes and complete and submit one?
expected_output:
1. Log in to Canvas and select your course from the Dashboard.  
2. In Course Navigation, click “Quizzes.” You’ll see a list of all available quizzes (graded, practice, or surveys).  
3. Find the quiz you want to take and click its title to open the quiz details page.  
4. Review any instructions or time limits, then click the “Take the Quiz” (or “Start Quiz”) button.  
5. Answer each question:  
   • If your instructor enabled one-at-a-time mode, navigate questions with the Next/Previous buttons.  
   • Otherwise, scroll through and answer all questions on one page.  
6. When you’ve completed every question, click “Submit Quiz.”  
7. Confirm submission if prompted.  
8. After submitting, view your results or feedback immediately—if your instructor has made results available.

input: How do Canvas instructors request New Quizzes access and how do root admins enable it?
expected_output:
1. Instructor Request  
   1. Contact your institution’s Canvas LMS Admin team (via help desk ticket or email).  
   2. Specify that you need New Quizzes enabled in your course.

2. Root Admin Enablement  
   1. Log in with your root-level Canvas Admin account.  
   2. Go to Admin > Account > Feature Options.  
   3. Find “New Quizzes” in the list and toggle it ON.  
   4. Save changes; New Quizzes will now be available in both beta and production.
context:
Document Title: What is New Quizzes

What is New Quizzes? New Quizzes is a quiz engine that integrates with Canvas and replaces the classic quizzes functionality currently existing in Canvas. Instructors can use New Quizzes to create quizzes using a variety of questions types. Students can take New Quizzes quizzes within their Canvas courses. New Quizzes: displays as assignments in the Assignments page can be duplicated is available in beta and production environments uses the Rich Content Editor to format and add content to certain quiz questions meets VPAT WCAG 2.1 accessibility requirements can be used alongside Classic Quizzes in a course The following New Quizzes features are not supported in the Canvas beta environment: Reports Statistics Item bank search Item bank tagging Outcomes added to Canvas in the beta environment after the beta refresh will not display in the New Quizzes beta environment. Outcomes must be added to the production environment to display in the beta environment. If you do not have access to New Quizzes: As an instructor, contact your Canvas LMS Admin team. As a Canvas LMS Admin, you can enable New Quizzes under your root account’s Feature Options. To know more about using New Quizzes, refer to the dedicated guides for instructors and students . To see a breakdown of how New Quizzes compares to Classic Quizzes, refer to the Classic Quizzes vs. New Quizzes Feature Comparison resource document.  Instructors Build Quizzes Instructors can use New Quizzes to build quizzes with several item types that measure student competency in a variety of subjects. Quizzes can be modified using various quiz settings and aligned to outcomes at the quiz or question level. Note: Currently, New Quizzes is not available in Free-for-Teacher accounts . Moderate Student Attempts Instructors can moderate student attempts and review students' answers . View Reports New Quizzes includes quiz reports for admins and instructors to view student performance , including mastery of learning outcomes. Students Complete Quizzes Students can access New Quizzes from a Canvas course to take a quiz. View Quiz Results Students can view their results from New Quizzes quizzes . Quiz results include overall and individual questions scores. They may also include instructor feedback.

input: What steps should instructors follow in Canvas to enable New Quizzes, create quizzes using the Rich Content Editor, configure quiz settings, and align quiz questions with learning outcomes?
expected_output:
1. Verify New Quizzes access  
   • If you don’t see New Quizzes in your course, request your Canvas admin to enable it under the root account’s Feature Options.  

2. Create a New Quiz  
   a. In your course, go to Assignments and click + Assignment.  
   b. Set the Assignment Name, point value, due date, etc.  
   c. Under Submission Type, choose Quiz and then select New Quizzes as the engine.  
   d. Click Save or Save & Publish to open the New Quizzes builder.  

3. Add and format questions with the Rich Content Editor (RCE)  
   a. In the quiz builder, click + or Add to insert a new question.  
   b. Use the RCE toolbar to add text, images, math formulas, or multimedia.  
   c. Select your question type (multiple choice, matching, fill-in-the-blank, etc.) and enter answer choices.  

4. Configure quiz settings  
   a. Click the Settings tab in the quiz builder.  
   b. Adjust:  
      • Availability dates and time limits  
      • Number of attempts and allowed retake policy  
      • Question grouping or randomization  
      • Scoring options (e.g., penalty for wrong answers)  
      • Accommodations (extra time for individual students)  
   c. Review overall assignment settings (points, assignment group, grading policy).  

5. Align questions to learning outcomes  
   a. In the quiz builder, open the Outcomes tab.  
   b. To align at the quiz level, click + next to “Align Outcome.”  
   c. To align per question, open a question and click the Outcomes icon.  
   d. Search for or browse your institution’s outcomes, select the desired outcome, and click Add.  

6. Finalize and publish  
   • Review all tabs (Questions, Settings, Outcomes).  
   • Click Save to keep it draft or Publish to make the quiz live for students.

input: In Canvas, within the text editor, which toolbar icons let me add a table or open the equation editor, and what keyboard shortcuts trigger those actions?
expected_output:
1. To add a table  
   • Toolbar icon: Click the Table icon (grid) in the RCE toolbar.  
   • Keyboard:  
     – Press Alt + F10 (PC) or Option + F10 (Mac) to focus the toolbar.  
     – Use the arrow keys to highlight the Table icon, then press Enter.  

2. To open the Equation Editor  
   • Toolbar icon: Click the Equation Editor icon (mathematical “∑” or “∫” symbol).  
   • Keyboard:  
     – Press Alt + F10 (PC) or Option + F10 (Mac) to focus the toolbar.  
     – Navigate with the arrow keys to the Equation Editor icon, then press Enter.  

Tip: Press Alt + F8 (PC) or Option + F8 (Mac) at any time to view all RCE keyboard shortcuts.
context:
Document Title: What is the Rich Content Editor RCE

What is the Rich Content Editor (RCE)? The Rich Content Editor (RCE) is an online editing tool for creating content. It includes a menubar, toolbar, content space, and other features that allow you to create content containing formatted text, hyperlinks, images, media, mathematical formulas, embedded objects, tables, and more. You can use the Rich Content Editor in the following Canvas features: Announcements Assignments Discussions New Quizzes Pages Quizzes Syllabus Learn more through the following resource: Rich Content Editor video  View Rich Content Editor The Rich Content Editor includes the content area, the menubar, and the toolbar. You can add and preview content in the content area . To format the page content, use the menubar options . You can use the toolbar options to format text ; insert links, images, media recordings, documents, or icons ; access the Lucid EDU suite ; open external tools ; format paragraphs ; clear formatting ; add tables ; insert math using the Equation Editor ; and embed media . To view all toolbar options, you may have to click the Options icon . Note : If icon creation is enabled by your institution, you can create icons and insert them using the Icon Maker . View Content Features The Rich Content Editor also provides general content management features. You can: view the HTML format code being used in selected text  open a list of keyboard shortcuts  open an accessibility checker  view a total word count  view and edit the content in HTML  open the Rich Content Editor to full screen  change the size of the content area by clicking and dragging the Resize icon  Open Keyboard Shortcuts You can use keyboard navigation in the Rich Content Editor. To view the Keyboard Shortcuts menu, click the Keyboard icon or press the Shift+Question Mark keys simultaneously. You can also open the menu by pressing the Alt+F8 keys (PC keyboard) or Option+F8 keys (Mac keyboard) simultaneously. View Keyboard Shortcuts Menu The following shortcuts are supported in the Rich Content Editor: To open the Keyboard Shortcuts dialog, press Alt+F8 (on a PC keyboard) or Option+F8 (on a Mac keyboard) simultaneously To focus the element options toolbar, press Ctrl+F9 (on a PC keyboard) or Cmd+F9 (on a Mac keyboard) simultaneously To focus on the editor's menubar, press Alt+F9 (on a PC keyboard) or Option+F9 (on a Mac keyboard) simultaneously To open the editor's toolbar, press Alt+F10 (on a PC keyboard) or Option+F10 (on a Mac keyboard) simultaneously To close a menu or dialog and return to the editor area, press the Esc key To navigate through a menu or toolbar, press the Tab key or the arrow keys You can also use other keyboard shortcuts

input: How do I display the full toolbar in the Canvas Rich Content Editor? Should I click the Options icon or press Alt+F10 on PC or Option+F10 on Mac?
expected_output:
1. In the Rich Content Editor content area, locate the toolbar.  
2. To reveal any hidden buttons, click the Options icon (three vertical dots) on the far right.  
3. (Keyboard alternative) You can also open the toolbar by pressing Alt + F10 (PC) or Option + F10 (Mac), but clicking the Options icon is required to see every tool.

input: How can I enable the Roll Call Attendance LTI at the account level and display its link in the Course Navigation menu for all courses?
expected_output:
1. Contact your Canvas admin or Customer Success Manager  
   • The Roll Call Attendance LTI must be enabled at the account level by your institution’s Canvas team.  

2. In the Account Settings, install/configure the LTI  
   • Go to Admin ▶ Settings ▶ Apps  
   • Click “+ App,” choose “By Locator” or “By Key/Secret,” and select the Roll Call Attendance tool  
   • Enter the values provided by the vendor or your CSM and save  

3. Verify Course Navigation placement  
   • The Attendance tool automatically appears as a visible link in every course’s navigation menu  
   • No further action is needed—students can’t see the link, so you don’t need to hide it  

After these steps, every course in your account will display the Roll Call Attendance link in Course Navigation.
context:
Document Title: What is the Roll Call Attendance Tool

What is the Roll Call Attendance Tool? The Attendance (Roll Call) tool is an external app (LTI) used for taking attendance in Canvas courses. The Attendance tool can be used for online or face-to-face courses. Enabled at the account level, the Roll Call Attendance tool can be used by all courses in the Canvas account. The Attendance tool always appears as a visible Course Navigation link, but it cannot be viewed by students, so hiding the link in Course Settings is not necessary. If instructors do not want to use the Attendance tool in their courses, no action is required. However, if you do use the Attendance tool, students can view their attendance report in the Gradebook through the Roll Call Attendance submission details page. Note: The Attendance tool must be enabled for your institution before it can be used in Canvas courses. If you are an admin, contact your Customer Success Manager for assistance.  View Attendance With the Attendance tool, instructors can keep track of course attendance by taking roll electronically. Instructors can choose to view the tool in a list or grid format and can customize the placement of each student in the seating chart. View Attendance Assignment When you take attendance using Roll Call, Canvas automatically adds Attendance as an assignment. The default point value for attendance is 100 points. To avoid Attendance calculation errors, never delete, rename, or unpublish the Attendance assignment. Note: Although students cannot view the actual attendance tool, they can still view the attendance assignment in the Assignments page. This assignment cannot be hidden from students. Take Attendance The status set for each student is associated with a percentage value. Statuses include present and on time, not present, late, and unmarked (excused absence). The Attendance tool also creates an assignment in the Gradebook and calculates attendance as a percentage of a student's grade. View Lateness Value By default, the value of being late is 80% of the present value. So if a student is late, the student will receive 80% for the day instead of the full 100%. The late value can be adjusted in Roll Call settings. View Gradebook Scores In the Gradebook Attendance column, by default, Canvas displays the assignment based on percentage of the point value. For instance, if the point value is 100, and roll call has been taken twice, a student with one present value (100%) and one lateness value (calculated at 80%) will have a score of 90 points, or 90%. The Attendance Gradebook column will update every time you take roll call in the Attendance tool. Note: Although students cannot view the actual attendance tool, if you are using attendance for grading, they can still view their attendance score in their Grades page and view their attendance report. You can prevent the assignment from triggering notifications by setting a manual posting policy for the assignment . Export Attendance Data At both the account and course levels, the Attendance tool allows users to create attendance reports. Note: Admins can also filter reports by SIS Course ID. Create and Manage Badges At the account level, admins can create and manage badges used in the Attendance Tool. At the course level, any badges added by a Canvas admin automatically appear for the course. However, instructors can also create additional badges for their course as needed.

input: How can I enable the Roll Call LTI in Canvas, record attendance (list or grid seating), set lateness, manage badges, and export attendance reports?
expected_output:
1. Enable Roll Call LTI  
   - Ensure the Attendance (Roll Call) tool is enabled at your institution’s Canvas account level.  
   - If it isn’t enabled, contact your Customer Success Manager or Canvas admin to activate the LTI.

2. Access and Record Attendance  
   - In your course navigation, click Attendance.  
   - Choose List view or Grid (seating chart) view.  
   - In Grid view, drag student icons to arrange seating as needed.  
   - Click each student’s status to mark Present, Late, Not Present, or Excused.

3. Set or Adjust Lateness Value  
   - Within the Attendance tool, open Roll Call Settings.  
   - Find the “Late” percentage and adjust the default (80%) to your preferred value.  
   - Save changes to apply the new lateness weight.

4. Manage Badges  
   - At the account level, admins navigate to Account → Roll Call Badges to create or edit badges.  
   - Instructors can add course-level badges by opening Attendance and selecting Add Badge.  
   - Badges created by admins automatically appear in all courses.

5. Export Attendance Reports  
   - In Attendance, click Reports.  
   - Choose Course or Account-level report.  
   - (Admins only) Filter by SIS Course ID if needed.  
   - Click Download to export the data as a CSV file.
context:
Document Title: What is the Roll Call Attendance Tool

What is the Roll Call Attendance Tool? The Attendance (Roll Call) tool is an external app (LTI) used for taking attendance in Canvas courses. The Attendance tool can be used for online or face-to-face courses. Enabled at the account level, the Roll Call Attendance tool can be used by all courses in the Canvas account. The Attendance tool always appears as a visible Course Navigation link, but it cannot be viewed by students, so hiding the link in Course Settings is not necessary. If instructors do not want to use the Attendance tool in their courses, no action is required. However, if you do use the Attendance tool, students can view their attendance report in the Gradebook through the Roll Call Attendance submission details page. Note: The Attendance tool must be enabled for your institution before it can be used in Canvas courses. If you are an admin, contact your Customer Success Manager for assistance.  View Attendance With the Attendance tool, instructors can keep track of course attendance by taking roll electronically. Instructors can choose to view the tool in a list or grid format and can customize the placement of each student in the seating chart. View Attendance Assignment When you take attendance using Roll Call, Canvas automatically adds Attendance as an assignment. The default point value for attendance is 100 points. To avoid Attendance calculation errors, never delete, rename, or unpublish the Attendance assignment. Note: Although students cannot view the actual attendance tool, they can still view the attendance assignment in the Assignments page. This assignment cannot be hidden from students. Take Attendance The status set for each student is associated with a percentage value. Statuses include present and on time, not present, late, and unmarked (excused absence). The Attendance tool also creates an assignment in the Gradebook and calculates attendance as a percentage of a student's grade. View Lateness Value By default, the value of being late is 80% of the present value. So if a student is late, the student will receive 80% for the day instead of the full 100%. The late value can be adjusted in Roll Call settings. View Gradebook Scores In the Gradebook Attendance column, by default, Canvas displays the assignment based on percentage of the point value. For instance, if the point value is 100, and roll call has been taken twice, a student with one present value (100%) and one lateness value (calculated at 80%) will have a score of 90 points, or 90%. The Attendance Gradebook column will update every time you take roll call in the Attendance tool. Note: Although students cannot view the actual attendance tool, if you are using attendance for grading, they can still view their attendance score in their Grades page and view their attendance report. You can prevent the assignment from triggering notifications by setting a manual posting policy for the assignment . Export Attendance Data At both the account and course levels, the Attendance tool allows users to create attendance reports. Note: Admins can also filter reports by SIS Course ID. Create and Manage Badges At the account level, admins can create and manage badges used in the Attendance Tool. At the course level, any badges added by a Canvas admin automatically appear for the course. However, instructors can also create additional badges for their course as needed.

input: How do I set up rubric criteria rows, performance level columns, and enhancements in Canvas? Also, what’s the difference between configuring rubrics at the account level versus the course level?
expected_output:
1. Setting up Rubric Criteria and Performance Levels  
   a. In your course, go to “Assignments” (or “Quizzes”/“Discussions”) and click the rubric icon or choose “Add Rubric.”  
   b. To add rows (criteria): click “+ Criterion,” enter the criterion name and description, then click “Add.”  
   c. To add columns (performance levels): click “+ Rating,” enter the level name (e.g., Excellent, Needs Improvement), define point values (or leave blank for non-scoring rubrics), and click “Add.”  
   d. Rearrange rows or columns by dragging their drag-handles, and delete any unwanted items with the trash icon.  

2. Enabling Rubric Enhancements  
   a. Go to “Account Settings” (or “Course Settings” if you’re an instructor).  
   b. Select the “Feature Options” tab.  
   c. Toggle on “Rubric Enhancements” to get improved visuals and functionality.  

3. Account-Level vs. Course-Level Rubrics  
   • Account-Level:  
     – Created in an account or sub-account; available to all courses there.  
     – Ideal for institution-wide or departmental standards.  
     – Once used in more than one place, it becomes uneditable but remains usable.  
   • Course-Level:  
     – Created directly in a course or copied from an account rubric.  
     – Editable until you use it to assess a student; after that you can’t modify it but can copy it for new assignments.
context:
Document Title: What are Rubrics

What are Rubrics? Rubrics are a way to set up custom or Outcome-based assessment criteria for scoring. A Rubric is an assessment tool for communicating expectations of quality. Rubrics are typically comprised of rows and columns. Rows are used to define the various criteria being used to assess an assignment. Columns are used to define levels of performance for each criterion. Rubrics can be set up as non-scoring rubrics, which allows for assessment-based and outcome-based grading without points. View a video about account-level rubrics or view a video about course-level rubrics . If enabled, the Rubric Enhancements feature option provides visual and functional enhancements to rubrics across Canvas.  Account Rubrics Account-level rubrics are rubrics that are created at the account or sub-account level. They can be used by any course within that account or sub-account for assignments, discussions, or quizzes. If an account-level rubric is used in more than one place, it becomes uneditable, but is still usable. Account-level rubrics can be used to create institutional or departmental question repositories. The purpose of account-level rubrics is to provide resources for teachers, not control content. For example, if the English department offered several courses to teach basic grammar rules to students, a department could create a sub-account level rubric. Instructors could then access the rubric to offer the same evaluation standards to students in different courses. Course Rubrics Course-level rubrics are either created at the course level or copied from the account or sub-account level. Once a rubric has been used to assess a student, the rubric cannot be edited. However, existing rubrics can be recopied and used on other assignments. When would I use a Rubric? Use a Rubric to: Communicate assessment expectations to users. Align pre-defined learning Outcomes to your course assignments and assessments. Assess online submissions in the SpeedGrader.

input: Where in Canvas can I create rubrics at the account/sub-account level and at the course level?
expected_output:
Account/Sub-Account Level Rubrics  
1. Log in as an admin and select the desired account or sub-account.  
2. In the left navigation, click Rubrics.  
3. Click + Rubric to create a new account-level rubric.

Course Level Rubrics  
1. Open your course.  
2. In Course Navigation click Rubrics (if you don’t see Rubrics, open Assignments and select the Rubrics tab).  
3. Click + Rubric to create a new course-level rubric.

input: How do I enable the Scheduler in Canvas, create office-hour appointment groups with specific slot capacities, and configure observer sign-up?
expected_output:
1. Enable Scheduler (Admin)  
   a. Go to Admin > Settings > Feature Options.  
   b. Toggle on the “Scheduler” (sometimes called “Appointment Groups”) feature.  
   c. Also toggle on the “Observer sign-up” feature (if available) so instructors can let observers register.

2. Create an Office‐Hour Appointment Group (Instructor)  
   a. In your course, open Calendar.  
   b. Click the Scheduler tab (or “+ Scheduler” button).  
   c. Click + Appointment Group.  
   d. Enter the Title (e.g., “Office Hours”), Location, Date, and Start Time.  
   e. Set the Appointment Length and Buffer (if desired).  
   f. Under “How many students can sign up per slot?”, enter your slot capacity (e.g., 1 for individual, >1 for groups).  

3. Configure Observer Sign-Up  
   a. In the same appointment group panel, check Allow observers to sign up.  
   b. (If you don’t see this checkbox, confirm step 1c with your admin.)

4. Publish the Appointment Group  
   a. Click Create Appointment Group.  
   b. Students and (if enabled) observers can now sign up via their Calendars.  

Troubleshooting:  
• If you don’t see Scheduler in your course Calendar, confirm the feature is enabled at the account level.  
• Observers only see slots once they’ve been enabled by the admin and the instructor.
context:
Document Title: What is the Scheduler

What is the Scheduler?
Scheduler is a
Calendar
tool that creates appointment groups within a course or group. Instructors can
create appointment time slots
, and students can
sign up for a time slot
within the appointment group. Some appointment time slots may only allow one student to sign up at a time, while others may allow an entire group to sign up.
If a student signs up for an appointment slot, an observer who is observing the student can view the appointment in the student's calendar. Observers cannot sign up for an appointment on behalf of a student. If enabled at the account level and allowed by the instructor, observers can also sign up for an appointment.
Note:
The Scheduler tool is optional in the Calendar. If you are an instructor and Scheduler is not available to you, please contact your Canvas admin. If you are an admin, contact your Customer Success Manager.
When Would I Use the Scheduler?
Instructors can use Scheduler to:
Create office hours
Schedule TA sessions
Schedule lunches
Assign presentation times
Host Student-Teacher conferences (students could also bring a parent or guardian)
Host other appointments

input: How can Canvas instructors configure Scheduler presentation slot durations, capacities, and observer signup eligibility?
expected_output:
1. Navigate to your course Calendar and click the Scheduler tab.  
2. Click “+ Appointment Group.” In the dialog:  
   • Enter a title, location, and optional description.  
   • Use the “Duration” field to set how long each presentation slot lasts.  
   • Set “Max Group Members” to control how many students may sign up per slot.  
3. To let observers sign up, ensure that observer–signup is enabled at the account level (contact your Canvas admin if it isn’t). Then in the appointment-group settings, check “Allow observers to sign up.”  
4. Specify the date range, meeting days, and start/end times for your slots.  
5. Click “Create Appointment Group.” Slots will auto-populate in the calendar with your configured durations, capacities, and observer-signup eligibility.

input: How do I update SIS data in Canvas using a CSV file? I see options like standard, FB, MT, and UI override modes; which one should I pick and in what order?
expected_output:
1. Prepare your CSV files  
   • Use Instructure format in this file order: users, accounts, terms, courses, sections, enrollments, logins.  
   • Either upload each .csv individually or compress them into a single .zip.  

2. Choose your import mode  
   • Standard (default) – Processes only rows in your file. Good for frequent, incremental updates (e.g., new enrollments).  
   • Full Batch (FB) – Syncs your Canvas data exactly to the CSV: removes any previously imported records not in the file. Use when you need to delete stale courses or enrollments.  
   • Multi-Term (MT) – Via the API, run a single import across multiple terms. Enable in your SIS import call and set a change threshold. Use when you manage several terms at once.  
   • UI Override – Forces Canvas to overwrite “sticky” UI changes (full name, sortable name, institutional email). Two sub-options:  
     – Process as UI changes (marks imported data as if manually edited)  
     – Clear UI-changed state (removes stickiness so future imports can overwrite)  

3. Determine your order  
   a. Initial setup (first import): use FB to seed data and delete unwanted records.  
   b. Term-by-term operations: switch to Standard imports for day-to-day enrolment or roster updates.  
   c. Cross-term bulk updates: use MT via API if you need to update multiple terms at once.  
   d. Data reconciliation: apply UI Override when you must re-sync names or emails that users have changed in the Canvas UI.  

4. Upload and monitor  
   • Go to Admin > SIS Imports, select your CSV or ZIP, choose your mode, and submit.  
   • Review the import log for errors and confirm data updated as expected.
context:
Document Title: What are SIS Imports

What are SIS Imports? The SIS Imports feature allows you to upload and integrate data from various Student Information Systems (SIS), complex databases, and even simple spreadsheets as comma separated value (CSV) files. Admins can use this feature to create users, accounts, courses, enrollments, logins, and more. Only admins with the correct permissions can import and manage SIS data. For more information please see the Canvas Account Permissions resource document . View a video about SIS Imports .  When would I use SIS imports? With SIS imports, you can: Import SIS data with CSV files or automatically import via the Canvas API Import SIS data with IMS Enterprise Specification XML zip files Import SIS data with Banner Grade Exchange Results XML Create an automated data integration with Canvas Import Types The SIS Import page supports a few formats for standard imports to Canvas: Instructure formatted CSV or zipfile of CSVs, IMS Enterprise Specification XML zip, or Banner Grade Exchange Results XML. A standard import only processes changes that are specifically listed in the upload file and is an efficient way to upload a few records. For example, if a student enrollment was listed as active in a prior import but not present in the current enrollment, no change will take place to the student enrollment. The enrollment will remain active until marked as deleted or completed in a standard import (or is marked as not present in a Full Batch update for the term where the course is listed). During the beginning of a term, course enrollments change regularly; submitting a standard import frequently helps keep enrollments current in an account. When uploading SIS data with CSV files, you may import an individual CSV text file or you may compress multiple files into a single ZIP file to bulk import data. If you are using the Instructure format for importing files, the files should be in the following order: users, accounts, terms, courses, sections, enrollments, and logins. Full Batch Updates Canvas supports full batch updates for each import type. This option will only affect data that has been involved in a previous SIS job – either created by a previous import, or referenced by a SIS job after a SIS ID was manually added. Manually created courses with no SIS ID, for example, won't be deleted even if they don't appear in the new SIS import. For enrollments, this option means the linked user and course/sections require SIS IDs. A Canvas record will be deleted if it is not included in the current import file. This option can delete large data sets without any prompt or warning for confirmation and affects data created in previous SIS imports. Full batch updates are useful if: Your source SIS software doesn't have a way to send delete records as part of an import, and you need to remove a fair portion of the imported data You want to be sure your current enrollment and data set are consistent with your SIS enrollment and course data Your SIS doesn't track changes to course state or enrollments for students and/or teachers You want to delete courses that you have migrated to Canvas from another LMS Multi Term Batch Mode If you want to run a batch against all terms in the same import, you can enable multi term batch mode. This mode can only be enabled in the API and requires a change threshold as noted in the SIS Import Format Documentation . UI Overrides Canvas supports user interface (UI) overrides through SIS imports. When a user makes changes to certain data fields in Canvas (e.g., a user's name), this change is "sticky" and is set as the new default. Selecting the Override UI option allows Canvas to overwrite any "sticky" data updated in the Canvas UI. Otherwise, attempting an import with conflicting data would be disregarded and the existing user data would not be changed. To view the full list of "sticky" data fields, see the SIS Imported Format Documentation . This option may be useful if: You forgot to restrict user options in account settings, such as allowing users to change their names, delete their institution-assigned email address, etc., and you want to run an update to be sure they are in sync. Note that this will NOT|Document Title: What are SIS Imports

settings, such as allowing users to change their names, delete their institution-assigned email address, etc., and you want to run an update to be sure they are in sync. Note that this will NOT impact the user's display name if they changed it. Only the full name and sortable name would be changed. You allowed them to change their names (above example) on purpose, but want to periodically sync with your current data. You want to maintain control over the names of users and courses, or if you know a name change occurred for a user or course. Overriding UI changes also allows one of two additional options: process as UI changes or clear UI-changed state. Process as UI changes. This option overrides changes that have taken place in the UI as "sticky" data; all data acts as if the changes were actually manually updated in the UI. This option may be useful if: You don't want subsequent imports to overwrite the data you are currently importing. Clear UI-changed state. This option removes the "stickiness" of all data that exists in this import; future imports with this data will not indicate any data in the UI as "sticky". This option may be useful if: You accidentally checked the "Process as UI changes" option and you need to fix the affected data. You forgot to remove the ability for users to rename themselves, course names, or remove the institutional email and you want to clear the stickiness of the UI changes that have occurred.

input: How can I set up a full batch update when importing my SIS CSV in Canvas to automatically remove enrollments for students no longer listed?
expected_output:
1. Prepare your Instructure-formatted CSV (or ZIP of CSVs) in the correct order (users, accounts, terms, courses, sections, enrollments, logins).  
2. In Canvas, go to Admin > Your Account > SIS Imports.  
3. For Import Type, select **Full Batch Update**.  
4. Upload your CSV or ZIP and click **Upload**.  
   - Full batch mode will remove any existing enrollment (or other SIS-managed records) not present in this import for items already stamped with a SIS ID.  
5. Monitor the import job; once complete, Canvas will automatically delete enrollments of students no longer listed.  

(Optional API method)  
• POST to `/api/v1/accounts/:account_id/sis_imports` with `batch_mode=true` and your CSV or ZIP attached to achieve the same full‐batch behavior.

To view the full list of "sticky" data fields, see the SIS Imported Format Documentation . This option may be useful if: You forgot to restrict user options in account settings, such as allowing users to change their names, delete their institution-assigned email address, etc., and you want to run an update to be sure they are in sync. Note that this will NOT|Document Title: What are SIS Imports

settings, such as allowing users to change their names, delete their institution-assigned email address, etc., and you want to run an update to be sure they are in sync. Note that this will NOT impact the user's display name if they changed it. Only the full name and sortable name would be changed. You allowed them to change their names (above example) on purpose, but want to periodically sync with your current data. You want to maintain control over the names of users and courses, or if you know a name change occurred for a user or course. Overriding UI changes also allows one of two additional options: process as UI changes or clear UI-changed state. Process as UI changes.
