input: How can I view my storage quotas, switch between file views like All My Files, and preview or download files in Canvas?
expected_output:
1. Open Files  
   • In Course Navigation, click Files.  

2. View your storage quota  
   • At the top of the Files page, see your personal quota and the percentage used.  

3. Switch between file views  
   • To view all course and personal files, click All My Files.  
   • To revert to the previous layout, click Switch to Old Files Page.  

4. Preview a file  
   • Click the file name to open the preview.  
   • Use scroll, zoom, or full-screen controls.  
   • Click Close or the X icon to exit.  

5. Download a file  
   • Click the File Options icon (•••) next to the file.  
   • Select Download.
context:
Document Title: How do I view course files

How do I view course files? Course files include any content uploaded to a course. By default, each course has 500 MB of storage space in Canvas (Free-for-Teacher accounts are limited to 250 MB). Administrators can change the quota for the entire institution or on a course-by-course basis. Files uploaded to a course do not count towards your personal file quota . If the Course Files link is shown in the Course Navigation menu, any user in the course can view course files. If you are an instructor, you can learn how to manage Course Navigation links . However, parents/observers may only be able to access certain course files.  Open Files In Course Navigation, click the Files link. View Course Files All published course files can be viewed by all course users . However, some files may restrict access to specific users. You can view your user quota and what percentage of that quota has been used . If you want to switch to the old view, click the Switch to Old Files Page button . Open Folder To view folder contents, click the folder name. Open File To open a file, click the name of the file . To download the file , click the File Options icon , then click Download . Preview File The file preview displays the file and file information details, as well as a link to download the file. You can scroll through the document, zoom in and out, and view the document in full screen. To exit the preview, click the Close button  or the Close icon . View All Files To view the files for all your courses and your personal user files , click the All My Files button.

input: Which 'Switch to Old Files Page' button opens the old Course Files page in Canvas?
expected_output:
1. In your course, open the Files area via the Course Navigation menu.  
2. At the top of the Files page, locate the button labeled “Switch to Old Files Page.”  
3. Click that button to load the legacy (old) Course Files view.

input: How can I view metadata like upload dates, file sizes, and access rights, and switch between different views in the Canvas Groups Files section?
expected_output:
1. Open your group  
   - In Global Navigation, click Groups and select your group name.  
   - (Instructors can also go through People in Course Navigation.)  

2. Access group files  
   - In Groups Navigation, click Files.  

3. View file metadata  
   - See columns for Name, Created date, Modified date, Modified by, Size, and Usage rights.  
   - Check the quota bar at top to see total and used storage (%) for the group.  

4. Switch between views  
   - Click Switch to Old Files Page to revert to the legacy view.  
   - Click All My Files to see files across all your groups on your User Files page.
context:
Document Title: How do I view group files

How do I view group files? Student groups have their own associated files. As a student, you may be added to a group within your course. Groups files include any content uploaded to your group workspace. As an instructor, you may be added to a group within your institution. Group files include uploaded assignment submissions, files for projects, and other group-related items uploaded to your group storage area. Notes: By default, each group has 50 MB of storage space in Canvas. Administrators can change the quota for the entire institution or on a group-by-group basis. Group files are automatically published when they are uploaded to the group. All group members have the same permissions to moderate files, including uploading files, publishing files, restricting access, and deleting files.  Open Groups In Global Navigation, click the Groups link , then click the name of the group in which you are a member . Note: If you are an instructor, you can also access student groups through the People link in Course Navigation. Open Files In Groups Navigation, click the Files link. View Group Files In the Files page, you can view the name of each file or folder , the date it was created , the date it was modified , the name of the person who modified the file or folder , the file size , usage rights (if enabled) , and the quota for your group and what percentage of that quota has been used . To switch to the old view, click the Switch to Old Files Page button . If you want to view the Files for all your groups , click the All My Files button . Canvas will display your User Files page with all group folders displayed below your user files. Notes: All files can be viewed by all group members. Group files are published by default. Files that have been submitted as group assignments do not apply to the group quota. Manage Group Files You can do the following: Search for files by file name . Add a folder . Folders can also house other folders . Upload a file . Set usage rights (copyright) for a file . You must set usage rights for a file before it can be published. Files that do not contain a usage right display as a warning icon. You can also rename , download , move , or delete files or folders. Notes: All group members hold the same permissions, so one group member can delete or move files uploaded by another group member. Group files can only be moved to folders within the group.

input: In Canvas Groups, which Files link in the navigation lets group members add folders, upload files, and set usage rights?
expected_output: Use the Files link in your group’s navigation (Groups Navigation). This Files page lets all group members add folders, upload files, and set usage rights.

input: How do I access the My Files folder in my Canvas account and check my storage quota percentage?
expected_output:
1. In Global Navigation, click the Account link.  
2. Click the Files link to open the All My Files page.  
3. Click the My Files folder to view only your personal files.  
4. On the My Files page, locate the storage indicator (usually at the top or in the sidebar) to see your total quota and the percentage you’ve used.
context:
Document Title: How do I view my user files

How do I view my user files? You can view your personal user files in your account Files area. User files include profile pictures, uploaded assignment submissions, and other files uploaded to your personal Canvas file storage area. Notes: No other users can view files in your user files. By default, each user has 50 MB of storage space in Canvas. Administrators can change the quota for user files for the entire institution. Learn more about file quotas . You can also view course files and group files .  Open User Files In Global Navigation, click the Account link , then click the Files link . View User Files In the All My Files page, all folders for your own files and course files display. To view your personal files, click the My Files folder . To switch to the old view, click the Switch to Old Files Page button . View My Files The My Files folder creates folders based on default events in Canvas. Once you upload a file related to one of these areas, the folder and accompanying file is created for you. The Conversation attachments folder : Stores files that you attach to Conversations messages. The Data Exports folder : Contains ZIP files created when you download assignment submissions from all your courses . Profile pictures folder : If your institution enables you to upload a profile picture, this folder stores photos that you upload as a profile picture. The Submissions folder : Contains copies of your assignment submissions; assignment are organized by course folder and displayed alphabetically. However, assignments submitted through an external tool are not copied to the Submissions folder. The Unfiled folder : Stores files that you attach to discussion topics or discussion replies (if attachments are allowed by your instructor). The Uploaded Media folder : Stores media recordings and files you insert, create, or upload. You can view your user quota and what percentage of that quota has been used . My Files also includes any additional folders you create to organize your files, as well as any files not uploaded to a specific folder. Any files in the My Files folder that are not related to assignment submissions count toward your user quota. Notes: As a student, files uploaded using the Rich Content Editor count toward your user storage quota. However, files uploaded as an assignment submission do not count toward your user quota. For online assignment submissions , if you submit a file that you've previously uploaded, you can delete the previously uploaded file after it has been submitted and free up extra storage in your user files. View Assignment Submission Folders If you are an instructor and have a student role in any courses, the Submissions folder contains copies of your assignment submissions; assignment are organized by course folder and displayed alphabetically. However, assignments submitted through an external tool are not copied to the Submissions folder. Note: For online assignment submissions, if you submit a file that you've previously uploaded, you can delete the previously uploaded file after it has been submitted and free up extra storage in your user files. View Course and Group Files Your course folders display below your user files . If your Canvas admin added you to a group, group folders also display below the course folders . You can easily move and organize files from your group, course, and user files. You can also view course files and group files directly from the course or group.

input: How do I access the Submissions folder under Files in my Canvas account to view the latest course submission copies?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas Global Navigation, click Account.  
2. Select Files to open the All My Files page.  
3. Click the My Files folder.  
4. In My Files, locate and open the Submissions folder—folders are organized by course name in alphabetical order.  
5. Browse the course folder to view copies of your latest assignment submissions.  

Note: Files submitted via external tools aren’t copied here.

input: How do I navigate to a file in Canvas Files and open the preview so I can scroll, zoom, use full screen, view file info, and download it?
expected_output:
1. Navigate to Files  
   - In your Course, Account, or Group sidebar, click the Files link.  

2. Open the preview  
   - Click the name of the file you want to preview.  

3. Scroll, zoom, and full-screen  
   - Scroll through the document.  
   - Use the zoom controls to zoom in or out.  
   - Click the full-screen icon for a larger view.  

4. View file information  
   - Click the Information (i) icon to see file details (size, type, last modified).  

5. Download the file  
   - Click the Download icon to save the file to your device.  

6. Close the preview  
   - Click the Close button or the Close (X) icon to exit the preview.
context:
Document Title: How do I preview a file in Files

How do I preview a file in Files? You can preview a file in a course , group , or personal user file storage areas.  Open Files In Course, Account, or Group Navigation, click the Files link. Open File Click the name of the file you want to preview. Preview File The preview displays the file contents . You can scroll through the document, zoom in and out, and view the document in full screen . To view file information details, click the Information icon . To download the file, click the Download icon . You can also view other files by clicking the Previous or Next buttons . To close the preview, click the Close button  or the Close icon .

input: In the Files preview, which button should I click to return to the Files list: Info, Download, Prev/Next, or Close?
expected_output: To return to the Files list from a file preview, click the Close button (or Close icon).

Document Title: How do I preview a file in Files

How do I preview a file in Files? You can preview a file in a course , group , or personal user file storage areas.  Open Files In Course, Account, or Group Navigation, click the Files link. Open File Click the name of the file you want to preview. Preview File The preview displays the file contents . To download the file, click the Download icon . You can also view other files by clicking the Previous or Next buttons . To close the preview, click the Close button  or the Close icon .

input: How do I open and select files in the Course Navigation’s Files area in Canvas? Are there keyboard shortcuts I can use, and how can I move files by dragging and dropping or using the Options > Move To feature?
expected_output:
1. Open the Course Navigation Files Area  
   • In your course, click Files in the left navigation.  

2. Select Files  
   • Click the checkbox next to each file.  
   • Keyboard shortcuts (PC/Mac):  
     – Select all: Ctrl + A / ⌘ + A  
     – Select individual: Ctrl + Click / ⌘ + Click  
     – Select range: Shift + Click  
     – Deselect all: Ctrl + Shift + A / ⌘ + Shift + A  

3. Move Files via Options > Move To…  
   • Hover over a file’s row and click the Options icon (⋮).  
   • Choose Move To…, pick the destination folder, then click Move.  

4. Move Files via Drag-and-Drop  
   • Click and hold the file name.  
   • Drag it onto the target folder in the folder list.  
   • Release when the folder is highlighted to drop the file.  

Note: Files are always sorted alphabetically; you can sort by any column header but cannot manually reorder.
context:
Document Title: How do I move and organize files

How do I move and organize files? You can move and organize the files you have access to by dragging and dropping files or using the Move options for each file. Files are always organized in alphabetical order, so you are not able to rearrange the organizational structure of files, but to locate a file you can always sort files by column. Learn how to view your user files , group files , and course files .  Open Files In Course Navigation, click the Files link. Move File via Move Button or Options Icon Locate the file you want to move. Click the line item for the file . To move the file via file settings, click the Options icon , then click the Move To... link . Select the folder where you want to move the file  and click the Move button . Move File via Drag and Drop To move a file using drag and drop, click the file name, then drag it to the desired folder. When the folder is highlighted, release your mouse. The file will be moved. Move Multiple Files To move multiple files, click the checkboxes next to the files you want to move . To select all files, click the Select All checkbox . You can also use keyboard shortcuts to select files: To select all files, press Control+A (PC) or Command+A (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select individual files, press Control+Click (PC) or Command+Click (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select a range of files, press Shift+Click keys simultaneously. To deselect all files, press Control+Shift+A (PC) or Command+Shift+A (Mac) keys simultaneously. Click the Options icon , then select Move To... link .

input: How are course files organized alphabetically in Canvas Files, and how can I move them using drag-and-drop or the Move To option?
expected_output:
1. File Organization  
   - All course files in Files are listed in alphabetical order by file name.  
   - You cannot manually reorder this view, but you can click any column header (Name, Size, Updated) to sort by that column.

2. Move Files via Drag-and-Drop  
   a. In Course Navigation, click Files.  
   b. Click and hold the file name you want to move.  
   c. Drag the file over your target folder until it’s highlighted.  
   d. Release your mouse—the file moves into that folder.

3. Move Files via Move To Option  
   a. In Files, locate the file line item.  
   b. Click its Options icon (•••), then choose Move To…  
   c. In the dialog, select your destination folder.  
   d. Click Move.

input: How do I access Course Files, add a folder, name it, move files inside it, and delete a folder?
expected_output:
1. Access Course Files  
   – In Course Navigation, click Files.  

2. Add a folder  
   – Click Add Folder.  

3. Name the folder  
   – In the Folder Name field, type your folder name.  
   – Press Enter (PC) or Return (Mac) or click Create Folder.  

4. Move files into the folder  
   – Locate the file you want to move.  
   – Click the file’s Options icon (three dots) and select Move.  
   – In the Move dialog, select your new folder and click Move.  

5. Delete a folder  
   – Click the folder’s Options icon and choose Delete.  
   – Note: Deleting a folder also deletes all files inside it.

input: How do I delete a Files folder and all its contents in Canvas using the Folder Options Delete link?

5. Confirm deletion if prompted—this action permanently removes the folder and all its contents.

input: What are the steps for permanently deleting files in Canvas using the Files navigation and Options icon? Are there any caveats regarding assignment submissions, unfiled files, or broken links that I should be aware of?
expected_output:
Steps for permanently deleting files or folders in Canvas:

1. Open Files  
   – In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link.  
2. Delete a File  
   a. Click the File Options icon (⋮) next to the file.  
   b. Select Delete.  
   c. Click Delete to confirm.  
3. Delete a Folder  
   a. Click the Folder Options icon (⋮) next to the folder.  
   b. Select Delete.  
   c. Click Delete to confirm (this also removes all files within that folder).  

Caveats to keep in mind:  
• Files submitted to an assignment can’t be deleted.  
• Once deleted, items cannot be recovered.  
• The Unfiled folder stores files linked elsewhere (e.g., Discussions); deleting these may break links or submission records.  
• Deleting a folder permanently removes all contained files.
context:

How do I delete a file or folder in Files? In Files , you can delete a file or folder in courses, groups, or personal files. Once a file or folder is deleted, it cannot be recovered. You can also locate your user files , group files , or course files . Notes: You cannot delete files that have been submitted as part of an assignment. The Unfiled folder stores documents, graphics, and any other files from your account that you have posted to different areas of Canvas, such as Discussions. Deleting these items within current courses may create broken links and submissions.  Open Files In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Delete File To delete a file, click the File Options icon  and then click the Delete link . Confirm Delete Click the Delete button. Delete Folder To delete a folder, click the Folder Options icon  and then click the Delete link . Confirm Delete Click the Delete button. Note: Deleting a folder also deletes all files in that folder.

input: If I confirm folder deletion via Folder Options in Account/Group/Course Files, are all its files permanently deleted?

input: Which options in Canvas Files let me download a course folder as a ZIP file, and how do I extract it on a Mac or PC?
expected_output:
1. Open the course and click Files in Course Navigation.  
2. Locate the folder you want to download.  
3. Click the folder’s Options icon (⋮) and select Download.  
   - Canvas packages folders as ZIP files.  
4. Once the ZIP file downloads to your browser’s download location:  
   • On a Mac: double-click the ZIP file to automatically unzip it.  
   • On a PC: right-click the ZIP file, choose Extract All, and follow the prompts to unpack the folder.
context:
Document Title: How do I download a file or folder

How do I download a file or folder? In Files , you can download a file or folder from any file storage area in Canvas. Learn how to locate your user files , course files , and group files .  Open Files In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Download File To download a file, click the Options icon  and then click the Download link . Open File Single files download as individual files. Open the appropriate folder to view the file. Note: Files download to the location where your browser saves downloads, which may be the Downloads folder on your computer. Download Folder To download a folder, click the Options icon  and then click the Download link . Open Folder ZIP File Folders download as ZIP files. To open the files within the ZIP file, either double click the ZIP file (MAC users) or right-click the file and select Extract All (PC users).

input: How do I download a folder as a ZIP file from Canvas using the Options icon, and then unzip it on a PC or Mac?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, open the appropriate Files area (Account, Course, or Group) via the Files link in the navigation.  
2. Browse to the folder you want to download.  
3. Click the folder’s Options icon (⋮) and choose Download. The folder is saved as a ZIP file to your browser’s download location.  
4. To unzip on a Mac, double-click the downloaded ZIP file.  
5. To unzip on a PC, right-click the ZIP file, select Extract All, and follow the prompts.

input: How can I navigate to Files in Canvas, download a file, edit it locally on my computer, and then upload and replace the original file?
expected_output:
1. Navigate to Files  
   – In your Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click Files.  

2. Download the file  
   – Find the file’s row, click Options (⋮) → Download  
   – Or check its box and click the Download icon  

3. Edit locally  
   – Open the downloaded file in your preferred editor  
   – Make changes and save  

4. Upload the edited file  
   – Back in Files, click Upload  
   – Select your edited file and click Open  

5. Replace the original  
   – When prompted, click Replace to overwrite the existing file
context:
Document Title: How do I edit a file in Files

How do I edit a file in Files? To edit a file stored in Files , you need to download the file, edit the file, save, and then upload the edited file.  Open Files In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Download File Locate the line item for the file . Then, click the Options icon  and click the Download link . Alternatively, you can click the checkbox next to the file name  and then click the Download icon . View File Your file downloads. Open the appropriate folder to view the file. Note: The file downloads to wherever your browser downloads files, which may be the Downloads folder on your computer. Edit File Open and edit the file using an appropriate editor on your computer. Save the file. Upload Edited File In Files, click the Upload button. Select File Click the title of the file you want to upload  and click the Open button . Replace Duplicate File To replace the existing file with the edited file, click the Replace button.

input: How do I download, edit, upload, or replace a file in my Account, Group, or Course Files using the Options icon or checkbox?
expected_output:
1. Open Files  
   • In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link.  

2. Download the file  
   a. Using the Options icon:  
      – Locate the file’s row, click Options (⋮), then click Download.

      – Select the file’s checkbox, then click the Download icon in the toolbar.  

3. Edit the file  
   • Open the downloaded file in a suitable editor, make your changes, and save.  

4. Upload or replace the file

      – In Files, click Upload, select your edited file, and click Open.  
   b. Replace an existing file:  
      – After clicking Upload, select the file name, click Open, then click Replace.

input: How can I locate and rename an unlocked Course Files folder in Canvas using the Options menu and save it without changing the file extension?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, open the course and click Files (or Settings → Files) to view your Course Files.  
2. Browse to the folder you want to rename and verify it does not display a lock icon.  
3. On the folder’s row, click the Options (•••) icon and select Rename.  
4. In the File Name field, change only the text before the period; do not edit or remove “.extension.”  
5. Press Enter (PC) or Return (Mac) – or click Save – to apply the new name.
context:
Document Title: How do I rename a file or folder

How do I rename a file or folder? You can rename your files at any time using the Rename option in the file's Options menu. Learn how to view your user files , group files , and course files . Notes: If you add a file to another area of Canvas (e.g. Modules or Assignments) and then rename the file in Course Files, the file rename will not update in any other Canvas location and must be changed manually. Please ensure that your file names are correct in Course Files before adding them to other content areas. You cannot rename files that were submitted as part of an assignment. You cannot rename files with a lock icon.  Rename File or Folder Open and view your personal user files , group files , or course files . To rename a file or a folder, locate the line item for the file or folder . Click the Options icon  and then click the Rename link . In the File Name field, change the name of the file or folder . To save the changes, press the Return (Mac) or Enter (PC) key or click the Save button . To return to the previous title, click the Cancel button . Note: Renaming or removing the extension in the file name may strip the extension from the file when it is downloaded. View File or Folder View the new name of your file or folder.

input: Are there some files in Canvas that I can’t rename, and how do I rename files without losing their file extensions?
expected_output:
1. Files you can’t rename  
   • Any file submitted as part of an assignment  
   • Any file displaying a lock icon  

2. Renaming without stripping the extension  
   a. Navigate to your User, Group, or Course Files.  
   b. Locate the file or folder, click the Options icon, and select Rename.  
   c. In the File Name field, edit the name but leave the “.ext” portion unchanged.  
   d. Press Return (Mac) or Enter (PC), or click Save.  

Note: If you remove or alter the extension (e.g., “.pdf”), Canvas may strip it when the file is downloaded.

input: In Course Files, what visibility icon and menu option restrict a file so it is only accessible with a link?
expected_output:
1. In Course Files locate the file and click its visibility icon (the Restricted Availability icon).  
2. From the Available drop-down menu select Only available with link.  
3. Click Save.
context:
Document Title: How do I restrict files and folders

How do I restrict files and folders? If you have access to a file in Files , you can edit permissions for files by: setting the state of the file (published or unpublished) restricting file access to only users who have the link scheduling availability dates for the file Note: You can also restrict a file or folder as part of setting usage rights for files or setting usage rights for folders .  Open Files In Course Navigation, click the Files link. View Availability The following icons may display next to files and folders to indicate their availability: Published : file or folder is visible, published, and accessible to all users (default). Restricted Availability : file or folder is visible to only those with a link to the file. Scheduled Availability : file or folder is only available during certain dates and times. Unpublished : file or folder is not visible. To edit file visibility, click the file's visibility icon. Note: If required by course or account settings, you may need to manage file usage rights before publishing . Manage Visibility To make a file available to only users with a link to the file, in the Available drop-down menu, select the Only available with link option . When new files are uploaded, the file visibility matches the setting specified in Course Settings . However, you can click the Visibility drop-down menu  and select another visibility option. Options may include the following: Inherit from Course, Course Members, Institution Members, and Public. To apply the changes, click the Save button . Notes: For course files, the option to make a file only available with a link applies to a file only when it is accessed through Course Files; if you add the file to another area of Canvas, such as Assignments or Modules, all students can view the file. If a file is only available with a link, course users who have enabled the Files notification preference still receive a notification when the file is added to the course. Schedule Availability By scheduling availability of a file or folder, you can give users a window of time to view the file. Students can view the file in Course Files as well as other areas of Canvas where the file has been added during the availability window. If students attempt to access the file outside the availability window, the file is inaccessible. To set availability dates, in the Available drop-down menu, select the Schedule availability option . Then, set the availability by start date, end date, or date range . In the Available from field, set the start date when users can view the file . To specify when the file will be available, select a time from the Time drop-down menu . If applicable, in the Until field, set the date when users can no longer view the file . To specify when the file will no longer be visible, select a time from the Time drop-down menu . You can select a date from the calendar, or you can enter a date manually. To apply the changes, click the Save button . Notes: If a file with scheduled availability is linked in another area of Canvas (such as Modules or Assignments), students will be able to see the name of the file, but if they click the file, they will see a message stating that the file has been locked and cannot be viewed until the specified date. Course users who have enabled the Files notification preference will not receive a notification when a file is added to a course if the student availability date restriction is selected. The time fields are optional and default to 12 a.m. if left blank. View File View the restricted status for the file. Hover over the Calendar icon to view the details.

input: How do I use the Schedule Availability option in the Canvas Files Available menu to set start and end dates and times?
expected_output:
1. In Course Navigation, click Files.  
2. Locate your file and click its visibility icon.  
3. In the Available drop-down menu, select Schedule availability.  
4. Set your start date/time in the Available from field and, if desired, set your end date/time in the Until field.  
5. Click Save.  
6. Hover over the calendar icon next to the file to confirm your scheduled dates and times.

Notes: For course files, the option to make a file only available with a link applies to a file only when it is accessed through Course Files; if you add the file to another area of Canvas, such as Assignments or Modules, all students can view the file. If a file is only available with a link, course users who have enabled the Files notification preference still receive a notification when the file is added to the course. Schedule Availability By scheduling availability of a file or folder, you can give users a window of time to view the file. Students can view the file in Course Files as well as other areas of Canvas where the file has been added during the availability window. If students attempt to access the file outside the availability window, the file is inaccessible. To set availability dates, in the Available drop-down menu, select the Schedule availability option . input: How can I assign a folder to my existing files in Canvas and have any new files I upload later automatically go into that same folder?
expected_output:
1. Create or open the target folder  
   • In Course Navigation, click Files.  
   • Click the +Folder button, enter a name, and click Create.

2. Move existing files into the folder  
   • In the Files list, select the checkboxes next to your existing files.  
   • In the toolbar, click the Options icon and choose Move To…  
   • Select your folder and click Move.

3. Upload new files directly into that folder  
   • In Files, click the folder name to open it.  
   • Click the Upload button (or drag-and-drop) and add your new files.  

Note: Canvas does not support a “default” folder for all future uploads—any file you upload from the root Files view must be manually moved or uploaded from within the folder to reside there.
context:
Document Title: How do I set usage rights and user access for a file or folder

How do I set usage rights and user access for a file or folder? If the copyright and license information requirement is enabled in your course or account, you have to set a usage right (copyright) for each file you upload to your course. Usage rights must be assigned to files before files can be published to the course. If the copyright and license information requirement is enabled in your course, you can set usage rights for all files that currently exist within a folder. Folders themselves cannot hold a usage right attribute, so the folder passes the usage right to the existing files in the folder at the time the usage right is defined. Therefore, you can create a folder, add all files to the folder, and then define the usage right for the folder and apply the right to all files at once. This action does not apply to any files added to the folder after the usage right is set. If additional files are added at a later time, you will have to reset the usage right for the folder or set file usage rights individually. Notes: If you are an instructor, you can manage course file usage rights requirements through the File Copyright course details setting . If you are an admin, you can manage file copyright and license requirements in Account details .  Open Files In Course Navigation, click the Files link. Manage Usage Rights of Individual File or Folder To manage an individual file or folder, locate the file or folder’s line item and then click the Usage Rights icon . Alternatively, you can click the File Options icon  and then select the Manage Usage Rights option . Manage Usage Rights of Multiple Files or Folders To manage multiple files or folders, click the checkboxes next to the files or folders you wish to manage . Alternatively, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts: To select all rows, press the Control + A (PC) or Command + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select individual rows, press the Control + Click (PC) or Command + Click keys simultaneously. To select a range of rows, press Shift + Click simultaneously. To deselect all, press Control + Shift + A (PC) or Command + Shift + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. In the toolbar, click the Options icon  and then select the Manage Usage Rights option . Select Usage Right In the Usage Rights drop-down menu , select one of the following five usage rights: I hold the copyright : file contains original content created by you I have obtained permission to use this file : file has authorized permission by the author The material is in the public domain : material is explicitly assigned to public domain, cannot be copyrighted, or is no longer protected by copyright The material is subject to an exception - e.g. fair use, the right to quote, or others under applicable copyright laws: the file is an excerpt or summary used for commentary, news reporting, research, or analysis in education The material is licensed under Creative Commons : this option also requires setting a specific Creative Commons license If known, enter the copyright holder information in the Copyright Holder field . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: If you are an instructor and are not sure which usage right applies to your file, please consult your institutional admin for guidance. Set Availability of Individual File or Folder By default, the file is unpublished. To set the availability of an individual file or folder, locate the file or folder’s line item and then click the Status icon . Alternatively, you can click the File Options icon  and then select the Edit Permissions option . Select File or Folder Availability and Visibility In the Available drop-down menu , you can publish or unpublish the file or folder . If you wish to restrict the file or folder , select the Only available with link or Schedule availability options . Select your preferred visibility setting . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: In Course Settings, visibility defaults to course visibility. However, for individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . Set Availability of Multiple Files or Folders To set the availability of multiple files or folders, click the|Document Title: How do I set usage rights and user access for a file or folder

individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . Set Availability of Multiple Files or Folders To set the availability of multiple files or folders, click the checkboxes next to the files or folders you wish to manage . Alternatively, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts: To select all rows, press the Control + A (PC) or Command + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select individual rows, press the Control + Click (PC) or Command + Click keys simultaneously. To select a range of rows, press Shift + Click simultaneously. To deselect all, press Control + Shift + A (PC) or Command + Shift + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. In the toolbar, click the Options icon  and then select the Edit Permissions option . Select Availability and Visibility of Multiple Files or Folders In the Available drop-down menu , you can publish or unpublish the files or folders . If you wish to restrict the files or folders , select the Only available with link or Schedule availability options . Select your preferred visibility setting . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: In Course Settings, visibility defaults to course visibility. However, for individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . View Updated Files View the updated files or folder. Note: To view files in the folder, click and open the folder name you set user rights and user access.

input: How can I bulk-select multiple files in Canvas, apply usage rights to them all at once, and set their publish, link, or schedule availability?
expected_output:
1. In Course Navigation, open Files.  
2. Select the files you want to update:  
   - Click each checkbox next to the file.  
   - Or press Ctrl+A (PC) / Command+A (Mac) to select all, Ctrl+Click (PC) / Command+Click (Mac) for individual picks, or Shift+Click for a range.  
3. Click the toolbar Options icon and choose Manage Usage Rights.  
4. In the Usage Rights menu, pick the appropriate license (e.g., “I hold the copyright,” “Public domain,” or a Creative Commons license), enter the copyright holder if known, and click Save.  
5. With the same files still selected, click the Options icon again and choose Edit Permissions.  
6. In the Available drop-down, select Publish or Unpublish, or restrict access with Only available with link or Schedule availability. Choose your visibility setting and click Save.

Alternatively, you can click the File Options icon  and then select the Manage Usage Rights option . Manage Usage Rights of Multiple Files or Folders To manage multiple files or folders, click the checkboxes next to the files or folders you wish to manage . Alternatively, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts: To select all rows, press the Control + A (PC) or Command + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select individual rows, press the Control + Click (PC) or Command + Click keys simultaneously. To select a range of rows, press Shift + Click simultaneously. To deselect all, press Control + Shift + A (PC) or Command + Shift + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. In the toolbar, click the Options icon  and then select the Manage Usage Rights option . Select Usage Right In the Usage Rights drop-down menu , select one of the following five usage rights: I hold the copyright : file contains original content created by you I have obtained permission to use this file : file has authorized permission by the author The material is in the public domain : material is explicitly assigned to public domain, cannot be copyrighted, or is no longer protected by copyright The material is subject to an exception - e.g. fair use, the right to quote, or others under applicable copyright laws: the file is an excerpt or summary used for commentary, news reporting, research, or analysis in education The material is licensed under Creative Commons : this option also requires setting a specific Creative Commons license If known, enter the copyright holder information in the Copyright Holder field . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: If you are an instructor and are not sure which usage right applies to your file, please consult your institutional admin for guidance. Set Availability of Individual File or Folder By default, the file is unpublished. To set the availability of an individual file or folder, locate the file or folder’s line item and then click the Status icon . Alternatively, you can click the File Options icon  and then select the Edit Permissions option . Select File or Folder Availability and Visibility In the Available drop-down menu , you can publish or unpublish the file or folder . If you wish to restrict the file or folder , select the Only available with link or Schedule availability options . Select your preferred visibility setting . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: In Course Settings, visibility defaults to course visibility. However, for individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . Set Availability of Multiple Files or Folders To set the availability of multiple files or folders, click the|Document Title: How do I set usage rights and user access for a file or folder

individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . Set Availability of Multiple Files or Folders To set the availability of multiple files or folders, click the checkboxes next to the files or folders you wish to manage . Alternatively, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts: To select all rows, press the Control + A (PC) or Command + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. To select individual rows, press the Control + Click (PC) or Command + Click keys simultaneously. To select a range of rows, press Shift + Click simultaneously. To deselect all, press Control + Shift + A (PC) or Command + Shift + A (Mac) keys simultaneously. In the toolbar, click the Options icon  and then select the Edit Permissions option . Select Availability and Visibility of Multiple Files or Folders In the Available drop-down menu , you can publish or unpublish the files or folders . If you wish to restrict the files or folders , select the Only available with link or Schedule availability options . Select your preferred visibility setting . To apply the changes, click the Save button . Note: In Course Settings, visibility defaults to course visibility. However, for individual files, the default is whatever the instructor selected in Course Settings . View Updated Files View the updated files or folder. Note: To view files in the folder, click and open the folder name you set user rights and user access.

input: What are the steps to upload files into my Canvas course? Should I open the Files navigation, click Upload, select my files, or can I simply drag and drop them into the Files area?
expected_output:
1. Open Files  
   – In Course Navigation, click Files.  

2. Upload via Browse  
   – Click Upload.  
   – In the file selector, choose one or more files and click Open.  

3. Or Upload via Drag-and-Drop  
   – Open your computer’s file window.  
   – Drag files into the Canvas Files area. They’ll begin uploading automatically.  

4. Handle Duplicates (if prompted)  
   – To rename the new file, click Change Name.  
   – To overwrite the existing file, click Replace.  

5. Monitor Progress  
   – A progress bar shows upload status.  

6. Confirm Upload  
   – After upload completes, verify your file appears in the course Files list.  

Note: Canvas limits individual file uploads to 5 GB (500 MB for media uploads).
context:
Document Title: How do I upload a file in Files

How do I upload a file in Files? You can add to your Files by uploading a file. As a student, you can upload files to both user and group files. Files can be used for assignments, discussion replies, and conversation attachments. Additionally, files in your user or group files can always be embedded in Canvas using the Rich Content Editor. As an instructor, you can upload a file to your user files and course files or move files from your personal files into course files. You can also import files using the Course Import Tool in Course Settings. Learn how to view your user files , group files , and course files . Notes: Canvas does not support file uploads larger than 5 GB. Video and audio uploads to Canvas through the media tool can be up to 500 MB in size. For assignment submissions, you can upload a file from your computer or select a file that has been previously uploaded to your user files. If you select a previously uploaded file, you can delete the file after it has been submitted and free up extra storage in your user files. Group files are automatically published when they are uploaded to the group. By default, files are published and visible to all users , however, if you are using Usage Rights, you must set the file usage rights before you can publish the file. You can learn how to bulk upload multiple files .  Open Files In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Upload File Click the Upload button. Open File Click the title of the file you want to upload  and then click the Open button . Note: You can also upload multiple files at once . Upload Files via Drag and Drop Some web browsers contain a unique feature that allows the user to add to files by simply dragging and dropping the files from a file window directly into the Canvas file repository. Click the title of the file you wish to add  and drag the file to your open browser . Your file will automatically upload. Replace Duplicate File If a file with the same name already exists in the folder where you are uploading your file, you will be asked if you want to replace or rename it. To rename the file, click Change Name button . This option creates a duplicate copy of the file with a different name. To replace the file, click the Replace button . View Upload Progress A progress bar displays to track the progress of your file upload. View Uploaded File View your file in the your account, course or group files page. Note: If you are using Usage Rights, you must set the file usage rights before you can publish the file.

input: How can I replace an existing file in Canvas Files with the same name without creating a duplicate?
expected_output:
1. In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click Files.  
2. Navigate to the folder containing the file you want to overwrite.  
3. Click Upload and select the new file (or drag-and-drop it into the folder).  
4. When prompted with the duplicate-file warning, choose Replace instead of Change Name.  
5. Wait for the upload progress bar to complete.  
6. Confirm the file has been updated in your Files list.

input: What are the Files & Course Import menu paths and steps for instructors to import or expand ZIP files under 5 GB in Canvas?
expected_output:
Files Import Path (for course, group, or personal files)  
1. Navigate: Course Navigation (or Account/Group) > Files  
2. Click Upload  
3. In file browser, select your ZIP file (< 5 GB) and click Open  
4. Choose:  
   • Expand It – unpack all folders & files  
   • Upload It – keep ZIP intact  
5. Monitor the progress bar  
6. When complete:  
   • Expanded files appear individually in Files  
   • Uploaded ZIP appears as a single .zip file  

Course Import Tool Path (to unzip into an existing folder)  
1. Navigate: Course Navigation > Settings  
2. Click Import Course Content  
3. For Select Content Type, choose Unzip .zip file into folder  
4. Under Choose File, click browse your file or drag-and-drop your ZIP (< 5 GB)  
5. Browse or select an existing folder (create one first if needed)  
6. Click Add to Import Queue  
7. Track status (queued, running, completed, failed) under Content Imports  
8. When complete, go to Files to view your imported content
context:
Document Title: How do I upload ZIP files in Files

How do I upload ZIP files in Files? Depending on your role, you can upload ZIP files to your personal user files, group files, or course files. If you are an instructor, you can also import ZIP files to an existing folder through the Course Import Tool. ZIP files containing internal folder structure retain that folder structure upon upload. If you do not know how to create a ZIP file, please consult your computer operating system's user guide. Notes: If you are using Usage Rights, you must set the file usage rights before the files can be published. Canvas does not support file uploads larger than 5 GB.  Import through Files You can import a ZIP file directly in Files . To access Files, you can open your personal user files , group files , or course files . In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Upload Files Click the Upload button. Open File Click the title of the file you want to import  and click the Open button . Choose ZIP Option If you want to expand all the contents of the ZIP file, click the Expand It button . If you want to upload the ZIP file intact, click the Upload It button . View Upload Progress You can track the progression of the upload by monitoring the progress bar. View Expanded Files If you selected to expand the ZIP file, the individual files display in Files. View Uploaded ZIP File If you selected to upload it as is, the file displays as ZIP file. Import through Course Settings You can also import files through the Course Import Tool in Course Settings. In Course Navigation, click the Settings link. Import Content into this Course Click the Import Course Content button. Select Content Type In the Select Content Type drop-down menu , select the Unzip .zip file into folder option . Choose File Click the browse your file link  or drag and drop the ZIP file to the Choose File tile . Open File Click the title of the file you want to import  and click the Open button . Select Folder Search for a folder  or select a folder . Note: You must upload the file to an existing folder. Create a new folder prior to uploading. Import File Click the Add to Import Queue button. View Import Progress The Content imports section displays the status of your import. Running reports display a menu bar with the time remaining to generate the report. Import statuses include queued, running, completed, and failed. View Files Open Files and view your imported files.

input: How can I check the status of my ZIP file imports in Canvas, such as which ones are queued, running, completed, or failed?
expected_output:
1. In Files uploads (Account, Group, or Course Files):  
   - After clicking Upload and selecting your ZIP, watch the progress bar next to the file name.  

2. In the Course Import Tool (Course Settings > Import Course Content):  
   - After you click Add to Import Queue, scroll to the Content Imports section.  
   - Each import displays its status (“Queued,” “Running,” “Completed,” or “Failed”).

input: How can I batch upload more than 50 course files (under 5 GB total) into Canvas Files? Should I upload them as a ZIP file or drag and drop them? And how can I set usage rights and handle duplicate files during the upload?
expected_output:
1. Package your files  
   - Because you have more than 50 files, zip them into a single ZIP (total size must be under 5 GB).  

2. Upload the ZIP  
   - In Course Navigation, click Files.  
   - Click Upload, choose your ZIP, and click Open. Canvas will automatically extract all files.  

3. Set Usage Rights  
   - After upload, select one or more files in Files.  
   - Click the “i” (Details) or three-dot menu for a file, choose Usage Rights, and assign the appropriate license.  
   - You must set usage rights before publishing.  

4. Handle Duplicate Files  
   - If Canvas detects an existing file with the same name, you’ll be prompted to:  
     • Skip – leave the existing file untouched  
     • Change Name – upload as a new file with a modified name  
     • Replace – overwrite the existing file  
   - Click the option that fits your needs.  

Tip: You can also drag and drop smaller batches directly into the Files pane, but zipping is more reliable for large quantities.
context:
Document Title: How do I bulk upload files

How do I bulk upload files? If you have a lot of files to add, you can bulk upload them in Files . You can also access your personal user files , course files , or group files . Notes: You can also bulk upload files by dragging and dropping the files into Canvas from your computer. However, sometimes too many files can cause problems. If you have more than 50 files, try zipping the files and uploading the ZIP file into your course. If you are using Usage Rights, you must set the file usage rights before the files can be published. Canvas does not support file uploads larger than 5 GB. You can also upload a single file .  Open Files In Account, Group, or Course Navigation, click the Files link. Upload Files Click the Upload button. Open Files Select the files you want to upload to your course . To select a group of files, hold down the Shift key on your keyboard and click the first and last files in the group. To select multiple files, hold down the Control (Windows) or Command (Mac) key on your keyboard and click each file. Click the Open button . View Upload Process View the progress bars for the file uploads. Drag and Drop Multiple Files You can also drag and drop multiple files to upload to your user or group files. Select multiple files and drag them to the files pane to upload them. Replace Duplicate File If a file with the same name already exists in the folder where you are uploading your file, you will be asked if you want to skip, replace, or rename it. To skip the file, click the Skip button . To rename the file, click Change Name button . This option will create a duplicate copy of the file with a different name. To replace the file, click the Replace button . View Files View the added files.

input: When I upload files in bulk to Canvas using drag-and-drop or Shift/Ctrl selection (for example, more than 50 files or up to 5 GB), how does Canvas handle duplicate files? Will it skip, overwrite, or rename them?
expected_output:
1. Canvas checks for existing filenames in the target folder during your bulk upload.  
2. If a filename already exists, you’ll get a Duplicate File prompt with three choices:  
   • Skip – leaves the existing file in place and ignores the new one.  
   • Change Name – uploads your file under a new name (Canvas appends a suffix).  
   • Replace – overwrites the existing file with your upload.

input: How can I view my Google Drive in the Canvas course navigation when using incognito mode and location-specific authentication?
expected_output:
1. Open an incognito/private-browsing window in your browser.  
2. Navigate to your Canvas instance and log in with your institution credentials.  
3. In Course Navigation, click the “Google Drive” link.  
4. When prompted, click Authorize.  
5. In the pop-up, sign in with the Google account you want to use.  
6. If authorization fails:  
   • Confirm you’ve signed out of all other Google accounts in your main browser.  
   • Disable or remove any Google-related extensions.  
   • Retry in incognito (this clears cookies and extensions).  
7. If you’re on a different network (e.g., at home), simply reauthenticate when Canvas prompts you—Canvas uses location-specific authentication, so you may be asked to sign in again before it grants access to your Drive.
context:
Document Title: How do I view my Google Drive files in Canvas

How do I view my Google Drive files in Canvas? If you have enabled Google Apps, you can view all files in your Google Drive account in Canvas. The Google Drive folder is accessed from the Course Navigation menu. Notes: You can only view one Google Drive account at a time in Canvas. Make sure you are logged in to the account you want to view in Canvas. If necessary, you can log out of your account and authenticate with a different account. If you are already logged into a Google account in Chrome, Canvas uses that Google account to authorize Google Drive access. If you want to authenticate using a different Google Drive account, you must log out of the Google account in Chrome and sign in to the account you want to use with Canvas. The location where you access your Google account may affect your access to Canvas. If you successfully authenticate with your account at your institution, you may have to reauthenticate when you log in to Canvas at home. Currently, you cannot access Google Drive files from course, user, or group Files in Canvas. You can only access Google Drive files from the Google Drive link in Course Navigation. Troubleshooting Tip: If your Canvas authorization fails, try logging in to Google Drive in Canvas using an incognito browser, which removes all browser cookies and extensions. If you are able to log in with the incognito browser, you are most likely logged in to Google Drive and/or Canvas with a different Google account. Confirm the account you are using for each location and try again. You may also need to confirm any Google extensions installed in your browser's settings.  Open Google Drive In Course Navigation, click the Google Drive link. Log in to Google Drive You may be asked to authenticate your account. Click the Authorize button. In an external window, enter your Google App email and password. Note: If you are unable to authenticate, please see the troubleshooting information in the description of this lesson. View Google Drive View your Google Drive files and folders. To view contents of a Google Drive folder, click the folder's name . To open a file, click the file name . To view your files in a list view, click the List View icon . To sorting options, click the Sort icon . Select a File To search for a file, enter the name of the file and click the Enter (Return) key on your keyboard. View Search Results Google Drive returns file results related to your search. Open File To open a file, click the name of the file . At the bottom of the window, click the Select button . View File In a new browser window, view the file in your Google account.

input: How do I link my Google Drive account to Canvas when I’m using incognito mode or when I’m on my home or school network?
expected_output:
1. Open an incognito (private) browser window  
2. Navigate to Canvas and log in with your institution credentials  
3. In Course Navigation, click the Google Drive link  
4. When prompted, click Authorize to grant Canvas access  
5. In the pop-up window, sign in with the Google account you want linked  
6. After authentication, your Google Drive folders and files display in Canvas  

Troubleshooting Tips  
• If authorization fails, ensure you’re completely signed out of all other Google accounts in your regular browser.  
• Disable or remove any Google-related browser extensions that might block cookies or pop-ups.  
• On home or school networks that require extra authentication, you may be prompted to reauthenticate each session—simply repeat steps 3–5.

input: In Canvas LMS, how do I log in, navigate course files (search, open, and edit them), and switch between multiple accounts?
expected_output:
1. Enable and open Office 365 in Canvas  
   - In Course Navigation, click the Office 365 link.  

2. Log in to your OneDrive account  
   - Click the Log In button.  
   - In the external window, enter your Office 365 email (or phone) and password.  

3. Browse your course files  
   - After authentication, you’ll see your OneDrive folder with file names, sizes, and modified dates.  

4. Search for a file  
   - Type the file name into the search field and press Enter.  
   - Canvas will display matching results.  

5. Open and edit a document  
   - Click the file name to open it in Microsoft Word Online.  
   - Edit directly in your browser; changes save automatically.  

6. Switch OneDrive accounts  
   - Click Logout in the Office 365 pane.  
   - Log in again with a different Office 365 account to view that OneDrive folder.
context:
Document Title: How do I view my Microsoft Office 365 files in Canvas

How do I view my Microsoft Office 365 files in Canvas? If you have enabled Microsoft Office 365, you can view all files in your Microsoft Office 365 (OneDrive) folder in Canvas. You can access the OneDrive folder from the Course Navigation menu. Notes : You can only view one OneDrive account at a time in Canvas. Make sure you are logged in to the account you want to view in Canvas. If necessary, you can log out of your account and authenticate with a different account. Currently, you cannot access OneDrive files from course, group, or personal Files in Canvas.  Open Office 365 In Course Navigation, click the Office 365 link. Log in to Office 365 You must authenticate your account. Click the Log In button. In an external window, enter your Office 365 email (or phone number) and password. View OneDrive View the files and folders in your OneDrive folder. OneDrive displays file name  and the date it was modified . Files display the file size . Search for Files To search for a file, enter the name of the file and press the Enter (Return) key. View Search Results OneDrive returns file results related to your search. Open File To open a file, click the name of the file. View File View the file in Microsoft Word online. You can edit the document directly in your browser if necessary. Log Out If you have multiple OneDrive accounts and need to log out, click the Logout link. You can log in again using a different OneDrive account and view those files in Canvas.

input: Through the Office 365 link in the Canvas course navigation, how can I switch OneDrive accounts, search for files, and open or edit them?
expected_output:
1. Access Office 365  
   - In Course Navigation, click the Office 365 link.  
   - If prompted, click **Log In** and authenticate with your Office 365 credentials.

2. Switch OneDrive accounts  
   - Click **Logout** in the Office 365 window.  
   - Click **Log In** again and enter the credentials for the other OneDrive account you want to view.

3. Search for files  
   - In the OneDrive pane, type the file name in the search field.  
   - Press **Enter** to display matching files.

4. Open and edit files  
   - Click the file name you want to open.  
   - The document opens in Microsoft Word Online, where you can view or edit directly in your browser.

View OneDrive View the files and folders in your OneDrive folder. OneDrive displays file name  and the date it was modified . Files display the file size . Search for Files To search for a file, enter the name of the file and press the Enter (Return) key. View Search Results OneDrive returns file results related to your search. Open File To open a file, click the name of the file. View File View the file in Microsoft Word online. You can edit the document directly in your browser if necessary. Log Out If you have multiple OneDrive accounts and need to log out, click the Logout link. You can log in again using a different OneDrive account and view those files in Canvas.

input: How does Canvas DocViewer preview PDF or Word documents in SpeedGrader? What are the file size limits, loading delays, and rules for downloading these previews?
expected_output:
1. Preview processor  
   - SpeedGrader renders PDF and Word files (.pdf, .docx, .doc) using Canvas DocViewer.  

2. File‐size and page limits  
   - Maximum preview size: 100 MB  
   - Maximum pages: 999  

3. Processing delay  
   - DocViewer may take up to 10 minutes after submission to generate the preview  

4. Download rules  
   - Files larger than 30 MB cannot display inline and must be downloaded  
   - Unsupported file types or files exceeding limits automatically fall back to download  

Troubleshooting tip  
If your file doesn’t preview, convert or resave it in a supported format and re-upload.
context:
Document Title: What types of files can I preview in Canvas

What types of files can I preview in Canvas?
You can preview a variety document types in Canvas. If the submitted file is an assignment and a Canvas DocViewer supported file type, the file is rendered by
DocViewer in SpeedGrader
. If the submitted file is not an assignment or a DocViewer supported file type, the file is rendered by Google Previewer.
Canvas supports previews for documents up to 100 MB and 999 pages.
Notes:
SpeedGrader may take up to ten minutes after an assignment is submitted to display a document that supports DocViewer.
Files over 30 MB need to be downloaded to view.
Troubleshooting Tip:
If an uploaded file does not display a preview, try uploading it as a different file type.
Document Preview Files
The following file types are supported by Canvas DocViewer:
.doc
.ods
.sxc
.docx
.odt
.sxi
.key
.pages
.sxw
.numbers
.pdf
.txt
.odf
.ppt
.xlsx
.odg
.pptx
.xls
.odp
.rtf

HTML located within a text file (.txt) cannot be previewed or annotated in DocViewer and must be downloaded to view the content.
Audio and video located within Powerpoint files (.ppt/.pptx) cannot be previewed in DocViewer and must be downloaded to view the content.
In the Canvas Teacher and Canvas Student apps, OpenDocument files (.ods/.odt) cannot be previewed in DocViewer. However, if you have a third party app installed on the device, you can use that app to view OpenDocument formats.
To preview Apple iWork files (.pages, .numbers, and .key), your Canvas account must be located within the United States.

input: How can I guarantee my .pptx file previews correctly in Canvas DocViewer? What are the supported file types, size limits (100MB or 999 pages), wait times, and how should I handle embedded media or reupload if needed?
expected_output:
1. Verify file compatibility  
   - .pptx is supported by Canvas DocViewer.  

2. Check size and length limits  
   - ≤100 MB  
   - ≤999 pages/slides  

3. Upload and wait  
   - Submit the assignment and open SpeedGrader  
   - Allow up to 10 minutes for DocViewer to render  

4. Handle embedded media  
   - Audio/video in .pptx cannot preview—students must download to play  
   - To improve in-browser viewing, remove or replace media with links  

5. Troubleshoot failed previews  
   - Convert and reupload as another supported type (for example, PDF)  
   - Ensure the new file still meets size/page requirements

input: Which image and video file formats does Canvas support natively, and what are the file size limits for conversion and uploading?
expected_output:
Here’s a quick overview:

1. Supported Image Formats (native Canvas previews)  
   - BMP, GIF, JPEG, PNG, SVG, TIFF (note: TIFF/TIF may not preview in all browsers)

2. Supported Video Formats (H.264–compatible playback in Canvas media player)  
   - FLV, ASF, QT, MOV, MPG, MPEG, AVI, M4V, WMV, MP4, 3GP

3. File-Size Limits  
   - Rich Content Editor conversion: up to 500 MB per audio/video file  
     • Files > 500 MB must be hosted (e.g., YouTube) and embedded  
   - Course, Group, and User Files upload: up to 5 GB per file  
     • Files above 5 GB cannot be uploaded to Canvas files
context:
Document Title: What types of media files can I upload in Canvas

What types of media files can I upload in Canvas?
Canvas can upload specific image, video, and audio files as user content.
When you
upload audio and video files in the Rich Content Editor
, Canvas converts files up to 500 MB. If a file exceeds the 500 MB limit, you can host the file through an external source such as YouTube and
embed it
using the Rich Content Editor. To learn more about available options for using media files in Canvas, view the
Canvas Media Comparison resource document
.
When you
upload a file
to your course, group, or user files, Canvas converts the file into a format supported by your browser. However, Canvas does not support uploading files larger than 5 GB to your user files.
Canvas files have quota limits set for each user area: user (personal) files, course files, and group files. Files uploaded directly to your user files or group files count against each specific quota, except for uploading a profile picture. All files uploaded into a course count against the course quota. For students, any attachments added as part of a graded assignment submission are uploaded into user files but are not counted against the user quota.
Note:
If you upload a file that is not supported by the Canvas media player, users can download the file to view outside of Canvas.
Troubleshooting Tip:
Media playback is determined according to browser, so if you cannot view a media file, you may need to try to view the file in another browser.
Supported Image Formats
Canvas accepts the following image files:
BMP - Windows Bitmap
GIF - Graphics Interchange Format
JPEG - Joint Photographic Experts Group
SVG - Scalable Vector Graphics
TIFF - Adobe Systems
PNG - Portable Network Graphics
Note:
TIF and TIFF file previews are not native to most browsers and may not preview in Canvas.
Supported Video Formats
The Canvas media player supports H.264 video playback. Canvas accepts the following video files for playback:
FLV – Flash Video
ASF – Windows Media
QT – Apple QuickTime
MOV – Apple QuickTime
MPG – Digital Video Format
MPEG – Digital Video Format
AVI – Digital Video Format
M4V – Digital Video Format
WMV – Windows Media
MP4 – Digital Video Format
3GP – Multimedia Mobile Format
For tips about media compressions and playback quality, view Vimeo's
Video Compression Guidelines
.
Supported Audio Formats
Canvas accepts the following audio files for playback:
MP3 – Digital Audio Format
WAV - Waveform Audio File
WMA – Windows media audio
WMV – Windows Media

input: How can I upload videos larger than 500 MB to Canvas? Are there limits to file size or storage quotas I need to know about?
expected_output:
1. Host large videos externally  
   - If your video exceeds 500 MB, upload it to a service like YouTube or Vimeo.  

2. Embed the video in Canvas  
   - In the Rich Content Editor, click the “Apps” or “Embed” icon.  
   - Paste the video’s embed code or share URL.  
   - Publish or save your content.

3. Be aware of file-size and storage quotas  
   - Rich Content Editor uploads (audio/video): 500 MB max per file  
   - User files area: 5 GB max per file  
   - Course and group files: subject to each area’s quota (view in Course Settings > Files or Group Settings)  
   - Student assignment attachments go into user files but don’t count against your personal quota

Troubleshooting tip  
If an embedded video doesn’t play, try a different browser or verify the external host’s privacy settings.

input: What steps must students follow to authenticate in Canvas Student app via institution-specific Canvas URL?
expected_output:
1. Install and open the Canvas Student app (iOS or Android).  
2. On the Welcome screen, tap Find My School.  
3. In the search field, enter your institution’s Canvas URL (either [your-school].instructure.com or canvas.[your-school].edu) or school name.  
4. Select your institution from the results to launch its login page.  
5. Enter your Canvas credentials (email address, username, or login ID) and password.  
6. Tap Log In.  
7. If you can’t recall your password, tap Forgot Password to reset it (depending on your institution’s settings).
context:
Document Title: How do I log in to Canvas

How do I log in to Canvas?
You can access Canvas through the following:
An institution-specific Canvas URL
Your institution's website
A
course invitation email
Additionally, you can log in through a Canvas mobile app designed for your role:
Students: Learn how to log in to the
Canvas Student iOS app
or
Canvas Student Android app
Instructors: Learn how to log in to the
Canvas Teacher iOS app
or
Canvas Teacher Android app
Observers/Parents: Learn how to log in to the
Canvas Parent iOS app
or
Canvas Parent Android app
You must have an account to log in to Canvas.
Notes:
If you are a student and were given a join code or a secret URL to join a course, learn how to
create a Canvas account
.
If you are not associated with an institution using Canvas and need an account, learn how to create
a Free-for-Teacher Canvas account
.
If you are an observer and do not have an account, learn how to
create a Canvas account
.
For some users, the user interface may appear differently if the New Login/Registration UI for Identity feature option is enabled at the root account level.
Troubleshooting Tip:
If you are unable to log into Canvas, view
logging in troubleshooting steps.
00:00:How do I log in to Canvas as a student?
00:03:You can access Canvas through an institution-specific Canvas URL. Canvas URLs use one of the following structures: [your institution's name].instructure.com.
00:15:or canvas.[your institution's name].edu. You can also locate your institution's Canvas URL using the Canvas Student iOS app or Canvas Student Android app. Some institution's may also allow access to Canvas via an institution-specific authentication system which redirects to Canvas, such as a school student portal or website.
00:39:After locating your institution's Canvas URL, you can log in to your Canvas account. To log in, enter your credentials (or login information) which may display as your email address, username, or login ID and password.
00:56:If needed and depending on your institution's settings, you may be able to reset your password by clicking the Forgot Password link.
01:04:If needed and depending on your institution's settings, you may be able to reset your password by clicking the Forgot Password link.
01:12:This guide covered how to log in to Canvas as a student.
Open Canvas URL
Using a
supported Web browser
, you can access Canvas through an institution-specific Canvas URL. Canvas URLs use one of the following structures:
[your institution's name].instructure.com
or
canvas.[your institution's name].edu
.
Learn more about
where to find your institution's URL
.
Some institutions may also allow access to Canvas via an institution-specific authentication system which redirects to Canvas, such as a school student portal or website.
Note:
Canvas Network and Free-For-Teacher accounts do not follow an institution-specific URL structure. Canvas Network accounts can be accessed at
learn.canvas.net
. Free-For-Teachers accounts can be accessed at
canvas.instructure.com
.
Log in to Canvas
After locating your institution's Canvas URL, you can log in to your Canvas account using your credentials (or login information). Enter your email address, username, or login ID in the
Email
field [1]. Enter your password in the
Password
field [2]. Then, click the
Log In
link [3].
If needed and depending on your institution's settings, you may be able to
reset your password
by clicking the
Forgot Password
link [4].
Notes:
If you are associated with an institution using Canvas and do not know your username and password, please contact your site administrator.
The Login page may display differently depending on your instititution or if you are logging in via a Canvas mobile app.
Get Started
If you are new to Canvas, you can learn about the
Global Navigation Menu
or about all the getting started resources available for
students
,
instructors
,
observer/parents
, and
admins
.
You can also watch
Canvas video guides
on a variety of topics.

input: How can I find my institution’s Canvas URL if my institution uses a specific domain, portal redirects, mobile apps, or CN/F4T links?
expected_output:
1. Check standard URL patterns  
   - [your-institution].instructure.com  
   - canvas.[your-institution].edu  

2. Visit your school’s website or portal  
   - Look for a “Canvas,” “Learning Management,” or “Student/Faculty Login” link that redirects to Canvas.  

3. Use the Canvas mobile app  
   - Open the Canvas Student/Teacher/Parent app  
   - Tap “Find my school” and search by name  

4. Use CN/F4T links if not affiliated with an institution  
   - Canvas Network: learn.canvas.net  
   - Free-for-Teacher: canvas.instructure.com
