input: In Canvas’s Rich Content Editor, how do I launch Lucid, select a file, configure access/view settings, insert it into my content, and save?
expected_output:
1. In the Rich Content Editor, click the Lucid app icon (if you don’t see it, click the Options (⋯) icon first).  
2. In the Lucid window, choose your diagram or board and click Continue.  
3. Under Access Settings, pick one of:  
   • Edit – others can edit, view, or comment  
   • Comment only – others can view and comment  
   • View only – others can only view  
4. (View only users) Click View Only Options to select pages, viewer type, and enable Automatically update when the integration loads if desired.  
5. Click Insert to embed the file into your content.  
6. Back in the Rich Content Editor, click Save (or Save & Publish/Update Syllabus/Reply as appropriate).
context:
Document Title: How do I embed a Lucid document in the Rich Content Editor

How do I embed a Lucid document in the Rich Content Editor? You can embed a Lucid document in the Rich Content Editor using the Lucid toolbar button. With your Canvas account, you get free full access to the Lucid Education Suite apps Lucidchart and Lucidspark . Lucidchart is an intelligent diagramming application that allows you to visualize complex ideas, systems, and processes. Lucidspark is a virtual whiteboard application that enables teams to ideate, design, and build better ideas. Before accessing Lucid from within Canvas, you must set up and connect your free Lucid account . Notes: If you cannot view the Lucid button in the Rich Content Editor toolbar, contact your instructor (as a student) or your Canvas admin (as an instructor). Learn more about using Lucid in Canvas .  Open Rich Content Editor Open the Rich Content Editor when using one of the Canvas features that support the Editor. Note: The Rich Content Editor supports keyboard shortcuts. To view the Keyboard Shortcuts menu, click the Keyboard icon or press ALT+F8 (PC keyboard) or Option+F8 (Mac keyboard). Open Lucid To open Lucid, click the Lucid app icon . Notes: To view the Lucid icon, you may have to click the Options icon . If the icon still does not display, Lucid may not be enabled for your institution. You can also access Lucid in the Rich Content Editor as you would to embed any document from an external app . If this is the first time you are accessing Lucid from Canvas in this course, you may be required to answer questions about your role and age. You may also be required to set up and connect to a Lucid account . Select File Select a file  and click the Continue button . Select Embed Settings You can select the type of access others have to your embedded document. In Access Settings, click one of the following radio buttons: Edit : other users can edit, view, or leave comments in the embedded document. Comment only : other users can view the embedded document and add comments. View only : other user can view the embedded document. Click the Insert button . Select View Only Options If you choose the View only access setting, you can choose which pages to display  and which Lucid viewer type to use . To enable or disable the embedded document to automatically update, click the Automatically update the document when the integration loads checkbox . Insert File To embed the file, click the Insert button. View Embedded File View the embedded Lucid document in the Rich Content Editor. Save Changes Click the Save button. Notes: The assignment, discussion, pages, and quizzes details pages display a Save & Publish button. The Syllabus page displays an Update Syllabus button. Discussion replies display a Reply button.

input: How can I enable Lucidchart in the Canvas Rich Content Editor, connect my account, open the Lucid toolbar, embed a diagram, set viewer access and auto‐update, and then save it?
expected_output:
1. Verify Lucid is enabled  
   - In the Rich Content Editor (RCE) toolbar, look for the Lucid icon (or under the Options (…) menu).  
   - If it’s missing, ask your instructor (students) or Canvas admin (instructors) to enable Lucid.

2. Connect your Lucid account  
   - Click the Lucid icon for the first time.  
   - Follow prompts to answer any role/age questions and to sign in or set up your free Lucid account.

3. Open the Rich Content Editor  
   - In your assignment, page, discussion, quiz, or syllabus, click the Edit (or Reply) button to launch the RCE.

4. Launch Lucid from the RCE  
   - Click the Lucid app icon in the toolbar (use Options (…) if needed).

5. Select the diagram to embed  
   - In the Lucid file picker, choose your Lucidchart (or Lucidspark) document and click Continue.

6. Configure embed settings  
   - Under Access Settings, select:  
     • Edit – users can edit, view, comment  
     • Comment only – users can view and comment  
     • View only – users can only view  
   - If you picked View only, optionally choose which pages to display and select a viewer type.

7. Enable auto-update (optional)  
   - Check “Automatically update the document when the integration loads” to keep your embed in sync.

8. Insert and save  
   - Click Insert in the Lucid dialog.  
   - Back in Canvas, click Save, Save & Publish, Update Syllabus, or Reply (depending on the tool) to finalize.

input: How do I open the Accessibility Checker in the Canvas Rich Content Editor, and then identify and correct errors in alt-text, color contrast, heading structure, and adjacent links?
expected_output:
1. Open the Accessibility Checker  
   a. In any Canvas page that uses the Rich Content Editor, click the Accessibility Checker icon (a circle with a checkmark) in the editor toolbar.  
   b. If issues exist, the icon shows a red indicator.

2. Review detected issues  
   a. The sidebar lists each issue type (e.g., Image alt text, Small text contrast, Heading structure, Adjacent links).  
   b. Click the Information (i) icon next to any issue to read more about the rule.

3. Fix alt-text errors  
   a. Select the image flagged in the editor; the sidebar will display an “Image alt text” or “Image alt filename” error.  
   b. Enter a concise, descriptive alt attribute (fewer than 120 characters) in the text field.  
   c. Click Apply.

4. Fix color-contrast errors  
   a. Locate the text flagged for “Small text contrast” (needs 4.5:1) or “Large text contrast” (needs 3:1).  
   b. Use the text-color or background-color picker in the Rich Content Editor to choose colors meeting the required ratio.  
   c. Click Apply.

5. Fix heading-structure errors  
   a. Find the highlighted heading in the editor; the sidebar shows if a heading is too long or if you’ve skipped levels (e.g., H2→H4).  
   b. From the Format menu, select the correct heading level (H2, H3, etc.) and keep titles under 120 characters.  
   c. Click Apply.

6. Fix adjacent-link errors  
   a. The editor highlights consecutive links pointing to the same URL.  
   b. Merge them into a single hyperlink or remove the duplicate link text.  
   c. Click Apply.

7. Cycle through multiple issues  
   • Use the Previous/Next buttons in the sidebar to navigate issues.  
   • After each fix, the checker automatically advances to the next issue.

8. Confirm completion  
   • When no issues remain, the sidebar displays “No accessibility issues detected” and closes automatically.
context:
Document Title: How do I use the Accessibility Checker in the Rich Content

How do I use the Accessibility Checker in the Rich Content Editor? The Rich Content Editor includes an accessibility tool that detects common accessibility errors within the editor. You can use the Accessibility Checker to design course content while considering accessibility attributes. This tool only verifies content created within the Rich Content Editor. You may use other accessibility tools to verify additional content in Canvas. All accessibility components retain the parameters set by your institution's Theme Editor template. The Accessibility Checker verifies the following accessibility rules: Adjacent links: Adjacent links with the same URL should be a single link. This rule verifies link errors where the link text may include spaces and break the link into multiple links. Heading paragraphs: Headings should not contain more than 120 characters. Image alt text: Images should include an alt attribute describing the image content. Image alt filename: Image filenames should not be used as the alt attribute describing the image content. Currently, files uploaded directly to Canvas create a redirect that does not properly verify image filenames. Image alt length: Alt attribute text is recommended to contain fewer than 120 characters. Large text contrast: Text larger than 18pt (or bold 14pt) should display a minimum contrast ratio of 3:1. Lists: Lists should be formatted as lists. Sequential headings: Heading levels should not be skipped (e.g. H2 to H4). However, the tool does not check if the first header starts with H2 or whether the headings are sequential with the rest of the content in the page. Tables do not begin with H1, which is designated for the page title. Small text contrast: Text smaller than 18pt (or bold 14pt) should display a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1. Table captions: Tables should include a caption describing the contents of the table. Table header scope: Table headers should specify scope and the appropriate structure. Table header: Tables should include at least one header.  View Accessibility Checker Notifications If any accessibility issues are detected within the Rich Content Editor, the Accessibility Checker displays an indicator . To view accessibility issues, click the Accessibility Checker icon . View Issues When an issue is detected, the Rich Content Editor highlights the affected area . The sidebar displays the accessibility attribute  and an explanation of the error . To learn more about the accessibility attribute, click the Information icon . View Additional Issues If the Rich Content Editor contains more than one issue , you can view all issues by clicking the Previous or Next buttons . Apply Fix To correct an issue, complete the task as noted in the sidebar . For instance, if the issue requires that alt text be added to an image, the sidebar displays a text field for you to enter alt text. When you are finished with your changes, click the Apply button . The Accessibility Checker will apply the fix and display information for the next issue. Continue to review and fix any detected issues within the editor. Confirm Fix When all issues have been fixed, or if no issues are detected in the Rich Content Editor, the sidebar indicates that no issues exist and will close automatically.

input: How does the Canvas Accessibility Checker find missing alt text, fix low-contrast issues, and make sure there are no accessibility problems?
expected_output:
1. Open your content in the Rich Content Editor and click the Accessibility Checker icon (a person with a checkmark).  
2. The editor will scan only content you’ve created in the Rich Content Editor against built-in rules:  
   • Missing alt text (images without an alt attribute)  
   • Low-contrast text (large text must meet 3:1; small text 4.5:1)  
   • Other checks (headings, links, lists, tables, etc.)  
3. When an issue is found, the editor highlights the element and opens a sidebar describing the error.  
4. To fix missing alt text:  
   a. In the sidebar’s Alt Text field, enter a concise description (under 120 characters).  
   b. Click Apply.  
5. To fix low-contrast text:  
   a. The sidebar shows the current ratio and required minimum.  
   b. Adjust text size, weight, or color (or background) in the editor until the ratio meets the threshold.  
   c. Click Apply.  
6. Use the Previous and Next buttons in the sidebar to cycle through all detected issues.  
7. Once all issues are resolved, the sidebar will report “No issues” and close automatically—confirming your content is free of the checked accessibility problems.

Image alt text: Images should include an alt attribute describing the image content. Image alt filename: Image filenames should not be used as the alt attribute describing the image content. input: How do I use the Rich Content Editor in Canvas to add and customize icons, including selecting icons, setting alt text, editing shapes, text, colors, cropping images, and applying changes?
expected_output:
1. Open the Rich Content Editor  
   – In an announcement, assignment, discussion, page, quiz, or syllabus, click the Rich Content Editor toolbar.

2. Launch Icon Maker  
   – Click the Icon Maker icon.  
   – To create a new icon, choose Create Icon Maker Icon. To reuse one, choose Saved Icon Maker Icons.

3. Name and Alt Text  
   – In Name, enter a unique title.  
   – In Alt Text, add descriptive text (or check Decorative Icon to disable).

4. Edit Shape and Style  
   – Shape: select square, circle, star, etc.  
   – Icon Size: choose small, medium, large.  
   – Icon Color: pick fill color.  
   – Outline & Outline Size: choose border color and thickness.

5. Add and Style Text  
   – Text: type your label.  
   – Text Size, Text Color, Text Background Color: adjust as needed.  
   – Text Position: choose top, center, bottom, etc.

6. Add or Upload an Image  
   – Click Add Image and choose:  
     • Instructure predefined (single- or multi-color)  
     • Course file  
     • Upload custom image (drag-drop or browse + Submit)

7. Crop and Adjust Image  
   – Shape: pick cropping mask.  
   – Rotation: enter degrees or use buttons.  
   – Zoom (Percent) or Magnifying Glass: resize.  
   – Reset: revert to original.

8. Save and Apply  
   – Click Save to store the icon in Icon Maker.  
   – Click Apply to insert it into the Rich Content Editor.  

9. Unsaved Changes Warning  
   – If you leave before applying, Canvas will warn you about unsaved icons.
context:
Document Title: How do I create an icon using the Rich Content Editor Icon Maker

How do I create an icon using the Rich Content Editor Icon Maker as an instructor? If enabled by your institution, you can use Instructure predefined images or upload your own custom images to make icons within the Rich Content Editor. You can also edit or delete icons you create. You can access the Rich Content Editor from Announcements, Assignments, Discussions, Pages, Classic Quizzes, and the Syllabus. Note: If the Icon Maker is not available in your course, it has not been enabled by your institution.  Open Rich Content Editor Open the Rich Content Editor when creating or editing an announcement, assignment, discussion, page, quiz, or syllabus. Open Icon Maker from Toolbar To add an icon from the toolbar, click the Icon Maker icon . To create a new icon, click the Create Icon Maker Icon link . To open a saved icon, click the Saved Icon Maker Icons link . Add Icon Details In the Name field , enter a name for your icon. To add descriptive text to your icon, enter the name in the Alt Text field . To disable Alt Text for your icon, check the Decorative Icon checkbox . Edit Icon In the Icon Shape drop-down menu , you can select the shape type you would like the icon to be. You can select between square, circle, triangle, diamond, pentagon, hexagon, octagon, and star shapes. If you would like to modify the size of your icon, use the Icon Size drop-down menu . To change the color of your icon, click the Icon Color drop-down menu . To add an outline to the icon, click the Icon Outline drop-down menu . If you would like to modify the size of your outline, use the Icon Outline Size drop-down menu . Edit Text Type the text you would like to include on the icon in the Text field . If you would like to modify the size of your text, use the Text Size drop-down menu . To change the color of your text, click the Text Color drop-down menu . To change the color of your text background color, click the Text Background Color drop-down menu . If you would like to modify the position of your text, use the Text Position drop-down menu . Add Image To add an image to your icon, click the Add Image drop-down menu . You can upload your own image , add an Instructure predefined single color image , add an Instructure predefined multi color image , or add an image from your course files . Add Instructure Predefined Images You can select from Instructure predefined single color or multi color images. Upload Image To add a custom image to your icon, drag and drop or browse for the file on your computer  and then click the Submit button . Crop Image You can crop the image to fit. To change the shape, click the Shape drop-down menu . To change the orientation, enter a number in the Rotation field or use the Rotation buttons . To change the size, enter a number in the Percent field or use the Magnifying Glass buttons . To reset the uploaded image, click the Reset button . To save your icon, click the Save button . Upload Course Image To upload a course image, click the preview of the previously uploaded file. Apply Changes To apply and save your icon to the Rich Content Editor, click the Apply button. View Unsaved Changes Warning If you navigate away from the icon maker before applying your icon, Canvas generates a message warning that you have unsaved icon on the page.

input: In Canvas’s Rich Content Editor, how can I upload an image, crop it (shape/rotate/scale), save the changes, and apply the image in my course content?
expected_output:
1. Open the Rich Content Editor  
   – In your announcement, assignment, discussion, page, classic quiz, or syllabus, click the Rich Content Editor toolbar.

2. Launch Icon Maker  
   – Click the Icon Maker icon .  
   – Select Create Icon Maker Icon.

3. Upload your image  
   – In the Add Image dropdown, choose Upload Image.  
   – Drag-and-drop or browse for your file and click Submit.

4. Crop and shape the image  
   – Shape: choose from the Shape dropdown.  
   – Rotate: enter a value in the Rotation field or use the rotation arrows.  
   – Scale: enter a percentage in the Percent field or use the magnifying-glass buttons.  
   – (Optional) Click Reset to revert any changes.

5. Save your icon  
   – Click Save to store the newly created icon.

6. Apply the icon to your content  
   – In the Icon Maker dialog, click Apply.  
   – Your cropped, shaped, and scaled image now appears in the Rich Content Editor.

Tip: If you navigate away without clicking Apply, Canvas will warn you about unsaved icon changes.

input: In the Canvas Rich Content Editor, which dropdown menus let me set the shape type and outline size?
expected_output:
1. Open the Rich Content Editor and click the icon you want to edit.

Document Title: How do I edit an icon made using the Rich Content Editor Icon

How do I edit an icon made using the Rich Content Editor Icon Maker as an instructor? If enabled by your institution, you can use Instructure predefined images or upload your own custom images to make icons within the Rich Content Editor. After you create an icon in the Rich Content Editor, you can edit the icon. You can access the Rich Content Editor from Announcements, Assignments, Discussions, Pages, Classic Quizzes, and the Syllabus. Note: If the Icon Maker is not available in your course, it has not been enabled by your institution.  Open Rich Content Editor Open the Rich Content Editor when editing an announcement, assignment, discussion, page, quiz, or syllabus. Open Icon In the Rich Content Editor, click the icon you would like to edit, then click the Edit button. Edit Icon In the Icon Shape drop-down menu , you can select the shape type you would like the icon to be. You can select between square, circle, triangle, diamond, pentagon, hexagon, octagon, and star shapes. If you would like to modify the size of your icon, use the Icon Size drop-down menu . To change the color of your icon, click the Icon Color drop-down menu . To edit an outline to the icon, click the Icon Outline drop-down menu . If you would like to modify the size of your outline, use the Icon Outline Size drop-down menu . Edit Text To edit the text you would like to include on the icon in the Text field . If you would like to modify the size of your text, use the Text Size drop-down menu . To edit the color of your text, click the Text Color drop-down menu . To edit the color of your text background color, click the Text Background Color drop-down menu . If you would like to modify the position of your text, use the Text Position drop-down menu . Edit Image To edit the image on the icon, click the Delete button . To add an image to your icon, click the Add Image drop-down menu . Save Changes To save your changes as a new icon, click the Save Copy button . To apply your changes to all instances of the existing icon within the course, click the Apply changes to all instance of this Icon Maker Icon checkbox . To save the existing icon, click the Save button . View Unsaved Changes Warning If you navigate away from the icon maker before applying your icon, Canvas generates a message warning that you have unsaved icon on the page.

input: How do I use the Rich Content Editor’s Icon Maker in Canvas? Specifically, how can I use the text field, the icon color dropdown, and the add image dropdown?
expected_output:
1. Open the Rich Content Editor  
   • Edit any Announcement, Assignment, Discussion, Page, Quiz, or the Syllabus  
   • Click the Icon Maker button and select or insert your icon, then click Edit  

2. Use the Text Field  
   • In the Text field, type the label you want on your icon  
   • Adjust text size via the Text Size drop-down  
   • Change text color with the Text Color drop-down  
   • Set a text background color via Text Background Color  
   • Reposition text using the Text Position drop-down  

3. Change Icon Color  
   • Click the Icon Color drop-down menu  
   • Select a predefined color or enter a custom hex value  

4. Add or Replace an Image  
   • Click the Add Image drop-down menu  
   • Choose “Upload” to add your own file or pick from Instructure’s predefined images  
   • To remove an existing image, click the Delete button next to the image preview  

5. Save Your Icon  
   • Click Save to update this icon only  
   • Or click Save Copy to create a new icon  
   • (Optional) Check “Apply changes to all instances of this Icon Maker Icon” to update every use of that icon in your course

input: How do I register and display Google Drive as a linked service in Canvas via Global Navigation > Account > Settings?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, open Global Navigation and click Account, then click Settings.  
2. Scroll to the Approved Integrations (or Registered Services) section.  
3. Find Google Drive and click the Connect (or +) button.  
4. Sign in to your Google account and grant Canvas the requested permissions.  
5. After authorization, verify Google Drive appears under Registered Services.  
6. To display Google Drive on your profile (if Profiles is enabled):  
   a. Click Edit Profile.  
   b. Check “Let fellow course/group members see my registered services.”  
   c. Ensure Google Drive is selected in the list.  
   d. Click Save Profile.
context:
Document Title: How do I connect to web services outside of Canvas

How do I connect to web services outside of Canvas? Canvas is integrated with a number of third party web services. Most of these services can be configured from the user settings page.  Open User Settings In Global Navigation, click the Account link , then click the Settings link . Link Services to Profile When you register other web services with Canvas, you can integrate your account with services you already use. Each of these services also generates a contact method for other people in your course or group. If Profiles is enabled for your account, and you want to show any of your registered web services on your profile page, click the Let fellow course/group members... checkbox. You can select specific services to display by editing your profile . Note: If you do not have a profile page, your institution has not enabled this feature. Connect to Web Services You may be able to integrate Canvas with the following web services: Google Drive Skype

input: How can I add Skype as a contact method in Canvas? I went to Account > Settings but I’m not sure how to register it so it appears on my profile.
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, click Account (Global Navigation) then Settings.  
2. Scroll to the “Approved External Services” (or “Link Web Services”) section.  
3. Find Skype in the list and click Connect.  
4. Enter your Skype username and click Save.  
5. To display Skype on your profile:  
   a. Check “Let fellow course/group members view my registered services.”  
   b. Click Edit Profile, check the Skype box under Contact Methods, then Save.

input: How do I connect and authorize Google Drive in my Canvas account settings?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas, click Account in the Global Navigation, then select Settings.  
2. Scroll to the Web Services section and click the Google Drive button.  
3. Click Authorize Google Drive Access to be redirected to Google.  
4. Select the Google account you wish to connect.  
5. Review the permissions request and click Allow.  
6. Return to Canvas and confirm Google Drive appears under Registered Services.
context:
Document Title: How do I connect to Google Drive as a web service in Canvas

How do I connect to Google Drive as a web service in Canvas? The Google Drive web service allows you to integrate Canvas with your Google Drive account. All users can authorize their Google Drive accounts for access to Google collaborations. If you need to create a new Google Drive account, please note that you may experience a delay with the Google integration in Canvas until Google has fully completed the account process. Note: For any of your courses, if the Course Navigation Menu includes a Google Drive link, your institution has enabled a global Google Drive integration. You do not need to enable Google Drive as a web service.  Open User Settings In Global Navigation, click the Account link , then click the Settings link . Register Google Drive In Web Services, click the Google Drive button. Authorize Google Drive Click the Authorize Google Drive Access button. You will be re-directed to Google to verify the authorization. Choose Account Click the account you want to authorize. Allow Authorization Canvas will ask permission to view and manage the files in your Google Drive account. Click the Allow button. Note: You may be asked to log in to your Google account before viewing this page. View Registered Services View Google Drive as a registered service in your Canvas account.

input: How do I integrate and authorize Google Drive in Canvas from the Account > Settings > Web Services page? Will there be any delays before it’s available to all users?
expected_output:
1. Navigate to Account > Settings In the Global Navigation menu, click “Account,” then click “Settings.”  
2. Open Web Services Scroll down to the Web Services section and click the “Google Drive” button.  
3. Authorize Access Click “Authorize Google Drive Access” to be redirected to Google.  
4. Sign in & Allow Select the Google account you want to connect, then click “Allow” when Canvas requests permission to view and manage your Drive files.  
5. Confirm Registration Return to Settings and verify that Google Drive now appears under your registered web services.  

Note: If you’ve just created a new Google account, it may take a short time (usually a few minutes) for Google to finish provisioning your account before the Canvas integration becomes available.

input: How do I set up Skype integration in Canvas, restrict its use within my courses, and enable students to send Skype friend requests?
expected_output:
1. Set up Skype integration  
   a. In Global Navigation, click Account > Settings.  
   b. Under Other Services, click the Skype button.  
   c. Enter your Skype Name and click Save Skype Name.  
   d. Confirm Skype now appears under Registered Services.  

2. Restrict Skype use within courses  
   – By default, Skype’s Canvas integration only lets users who’ve registered Skype add each other if they share a course.  
   – There is no per-course on/off switch. To disable Skype site-wide, ask your Canvas administrator to remove Skype from Supported Services.  

3. Enable students to send Skype friend requests  
   a. Instruct each student to complete the steps above.  
   b. Once registered and enrolled together, students can view classmates in People and click the Skype icon on a user’s profile card to send a friend request.

Document Title: How do I connect to Skype as a web service in Canvas

How do I connect to Skype as a web service in Canvas? You can connect to the Skype web service in Canvas. This integration allows you to send friend requests to other users in your course who have also connected to Skype. It does not allow you to use Skype directly in Canvas.  Open User Settings In Global Navigation, click the Account link , then click the Settings link . Register Skype In the Other Services section, click the Skype button. Log in to Skype Enter your Skype name in the Skype Name field . Click the Save Skype Name button . Skype displays under the Registered Services heading in your Canvas settings.

input: How do I add my Skype name in Canvas Settings under Other Services so I can send connection requests to my classmates?
expected_output:
1. In Canvas’s Global Navigation, click Account, then select Settings.  
2. Under Other Services, click the Skype button.  
3. Enter your Skype name in the Skype Name field.  
4. Click Save Skype Name.  
5. Confirm that Skype now appears under Registered Services.  
  
You can now send Skype connection requests to classmates who’ve also registered their Skype name.

input: How do I enable the C4E toggle in the settings of a specific sub-account in Canvas?
expected_output:
1. Log in to Canvas as an admin and navigate to the Admin menu.  
2. Select the parent account, then choose the sub-account you want to configure.  
3. Click Settings in the sub-account sidebar.  
4. Open the Feature Options tab.  
5. Locate the “Canvas for Elementary” (C4E) option and switch the toggle to On.  
6. Scroll down and click Save Settings.
context:
Document Title: Canvas for Elementary FAQ

Canvas for Elementary FAQ
This document includes some of the most frequently asked questions about Canvas for Elementary.
How do I enable Canvas for Elementary?
Admins can enable the Canvas for Elementary setting for specific sub-accounts.
View how to enable Canvas for Elementary in a sub-account
.
Can I enable Canvas for Elementary for secondary school (6-12) sub-accounts?
Canvas for Elementary is intended for K-5 users; however, it can be enabled for any institution's sub-account.
When will upcoming features be available?
See
Canvas for Elementary Releases
for the projected feature release timeline.
Are all features available in the Canvas Student App?
The Canvas Mobile team is working to provide as many of these features as possible within the Canvas Student app. Please watch
the Canvas for Elementary group
for updated information, mobile designs, and release timelines.
What is the recommended set up for Canvas for Elementary?
We recommend that every instructor have a dedicated course for their Homeroom. Once a course is designated as a homeroom course, functionality is limited to the items that are needed to manage the content on the dashboard.
We also recommend that instructors have a separate course for every subject that they teach so they display as a subject card on the dashboard for students. This will help the instructor to keep their content and grading organized and will help focus students.
What is the recommended SIS course structure?
We recommend having separate courses for each subject. To create separate courses in Canvas, keep student enrollments current and allow instructors to manage course subject content. Provision data from your SIS to have separate courses or sections sync from your SIS to Canvas for each subject if possible. If you are not able to sync from your SIS, you may be able to create courses manually if allowed by your institution's Canvas admin. If course subjects are created manually, course enrollments must be managed manually as well. However, we are exploring options to help manage enrollments automatically.
How do I designate homeroom courses when importing SIS files?
When
importing a courses csv file
, you can designate homeroom courses using a "homeroom_course" column.
Does Canvas for Elementary work with blueprint courses?
Yes. Individual subject courses can be synced with a blueprint course. We recommend creating the blueprint course in a sub-account that has Canvas for Elementary enabled so you can use student view and/or act as a student. When using a blueprint course as a homeroom, be sure to
enable the homeroom setting
.
How are subject cards created on the Homeroom Dashboard?
Subject cards are created for published subjects in which a student is enrolled.
Can students view manually-created courses on the Homeroom Dashboard?
If the course has been published and the student is enrolled in the course, it displays on the Homeroom Dashboard.
How do I designate a course as the homeroom course?
A course can be designated as the homeroom course in course settings.
View how to designate a course as the homeroom course
.
Can Canvas for Elementary courses be taught by various instructors?
Yes. Course subjects can be taught by one or multiple instructors.
How will instructors view changes in a Canvas for Elementary course?
For the time being, not much will change from the instructor view. Canvas for Elementary course instructors can use student view to see what displays for students.
How long does a Homeroom or Subject announcement display?
The Homeroom and subject pages display the most recent Homeroom or subject announcement, if one has been added in the last two weeks. Previously posted announcements can be accessed using the Previous button.
Can I use module prerequisites and requirements for a Canvas for Elementary subject?
Yes. All prerequisites, requirements, and availability dates will be honored if set.
What conferencing tools are supported in the Schedule tab?
In future updates, instructors can add online class meetings to the schedule. Our goal is to support as many tools as possible with this functionality, including Zoom, Teams, Google Meet, and BBB.|Document Title: Canvas for Elementary FAQ

In future updates, instructors can add online class meetings to the schedule. Our goal is to support as many tools as possible with this functionality, including Zoom, Teams, Google Meet, and BBB.
Where will LTI tools linked in course navigation appear in Canvas for Elementary subjects?
In future updates, LTI tools that typically show in the Course Navigation will show as a tab in that subject.
How are resources added to the Dashboard Resources tab?
The
Important Info section is populated by the homeroom teacher (instructor)
. LTI tools enabled for the sub-account will display to students in the Student Applications section.
If content is not added to the Important Info section, the Important Info section does not display. Similarly, if LTI tools have not been enabled, the Student Applications section does not display.
How are important dates determined?
Instructors can use the
Mark as important date and show on homeroom sidebar
checkbox to designate an assignment, graded discussion, quiz, and subject event as an important date. Important date items display in the Homeroom sidebar. Differentiated assignments marked with an important date display the due date assigned to the student in the Homeroom sidebar.
How are items completed in the schedule?
Online assignments are checked off as soon as the assignment is submitted. On paper and no submissions assignments must be manually checked off in the schedule by the student.
Can I hide the Grades tab in a subject or on the Homeroom Dashboard?
Instructors can hide a subject's Grades tab using
course navigation settings
. Once a subject's Grades tab has been hidden, grades for that subject do not display on the Homeroom Grades tab.
If the Grades tab is removed for all subjects a student is enrolled in, the Homeroom Grades tab does not display.
Can I hide the Resources tab in a subject or on the Homeroom Dashboard?
The Resources tab cannot be hidden on the Homeroom Dashboard.
A subject's Resources tab is automatically hidden if the subject does not include any external applications and does not have information included in the
Important Info
section.

input: Which course navigation option in Canvas hides the "Grades" and "Homeroom Grades" tabs?
expected_output:
1. In your subject course, go to Settings > Navigation.  
2. Locate the Grades link in the list of navigation items.  
3. Drag Grades down into the hidden section (or click its ••• menu and choose Disable).  
4. Click Save at the bottom of the page.  

Once you’ve hidden Grades in a course, that course’s Grades tab won’t display—and if you hide Grades in every subject course, the Homeroom Grades tab is automatically removed.
context:
Document Title: Canvas for Elementary FAQ

Canvas for Elementary FAQ
This document includes some of the most frequently asked questions about Canvas for Elementary.
How do I enable Canvas for Elementary?
Admins can enable the Canvas for Elementary setting for specific sub-accounts.
View how to enable Canvas for Elementary in a sub-account
.
Can I enable Canvas for Elementary for secondary school (6-12) sub-accounts?
Canvas for Elementary is intended for K-5 users; however, it can be enabled for any institution's sub-account.
When will upcoming features be available?
See
Canvas for Elementary Releases
for the projected feature release timeline.
Are all features available in the Canvas Student App?
The Canvas Mobile team is working to provide as many of these features as possible within the Canvas Student app. Please watch
the Canvas for Elementary group
for updated information, mobile designs, and release timelines.
What is the recommended set up for Canvas for Elementary?
We recommend that every instructor have a dedicated course for their Homeroom. Once a course is designated as a homeroom course, functionality is limited to the items that are needed to manage the content on the dashboard.
We also recommend that instructors have a separate course for every subject that they teach so they display as a subject card on the dashboard for students. This will help the instructor to keep their content and grading organized and will help focus students.
What is the recommended SIS course structure?
We recommend having separate courses for each subject. To create separate courses in Canvas, keep student enrollments current and allow instructors to manage course subject content. Provision data from your SIS to have separate courses or sections sync from your SIS to Canvas for each subject if possible. If you are not able to sync from your SIS, you may be able to create courses manually if allowed by your institution's Canvas admin. If course subjects are created manually, course enrollments must be managed manually as well. However, we are exploring options to help manage enrollments automatically.
How do I designate homeroom courses when importing SIS files?
When
importing a courses csv file
, you can designate homeroom courses using a "homeroom_course" column.
Does Canvas for Elementary work with blueprint courses?
Yes. Individual subject courses can be synced with a blueprint course. We recommend creating the blueprint course in a sub-account that has Canvas for Elementary enabled so you can use student view and/or act as a student. When using a blueprint course as a homeroom, be sure to
enable the homeroom setting
.
How are subject cards created on the Homeroom Dashboard?
Subject cards are created for published subjects in which a student is enrolled.
Can students view manually-created courses on the Homeroom Dashboard?
If the course has been published and the student is enrolled in the course, it displays on the Homeroom Dashboard.
How do I designate a course as the homeroom course?
A course can be designated as the homeroom course in course settings.
View how to designate a course as the homeroom course
.
Can Canvas for Elementary courses be taught by various instructors?
Yes. Course subjects can be taught by one or multiple instructors.
How will instructors view changes in a Canvas for Elementary course?
For the time being, not much will change from the instructor view. Canvas for Elementary course instructors can use student view to see what displays for students.
How long does a Homeroom or Subject announcement display?
The Homeroom and subject pages display the most recent Homeroom or subject announcement, if one has been added in the last two weeks. Previously posted announcements can be accessed using the Previous button.
Can I use module prerequisites and requirements for a Canvas for Elementary subject?
Yes. All prerequisites, requirements, and availability dates will be honored if set.
What conferencing tools are supported in the Schedule tab?
In future updates, instructors can add online class meetings to the schedule. Our goal is to support as many tools as possible with this functionality, including Zoom, Teams, Google Meet, and BBB.|Document Title: Canvas for Elementary FAQ

In future updates, instructors can add online class meetings to the schedule. Our goal is to support as many tools as possible with this functionality, including Zoom, Teams, Google Meet, and BBB.
Where will LTI tools linked in course navigation appear in Canvas for Elementary subjects?
In future updates, LTI tools that typically show in the Course Navigation will show as a tab in that subject.
How are resources added to the Dashboard Resources tab?
The
Important Info section is populated by the homeroom teacher (instructor)
. LTI tools enabled for the sub-account will display to students in the Student Applications section.
If content is not added to the Important Info section, the Important Info section does not display. Similarly, if LTI tools have not been enabled, the Student Applications section does not display.
How are important dates determined?
Instructors can use the
Mark as important date and show on homeroom sidebar
checkbox to designate an assignment, graded discussion, quiz, and subject event as an important date. Important date items display in the Homeroom sidebar. Differentiated assignments marked with an important date display the due date assigned to the student in the Homeroom sidebar.
How are items completed in the schedule?
Online assignments are checked off as soon as the assignment is submitted. On paper and no submissions assignments must be manually checked off in the schedule by the student.
Can I hide the Grades tab in a subject or on the Homeroom Dashboard?
Instructors can hide a subject's Grades tab using
course navigation settings
. Once a subject's Grades tab has been hidden, grades for that subject do not display on the Homeroom Grades tab.
If the Grades tab is removed for all subjects a student is enrolled in, the Homeroom Grades tab does not display.
Can I hide the Resources tab in a subject or on the Homeroom Dashboard?
The Resources tab cannot be hidden on the Homeroom Dashboard.
A subject's Resources tab is automatically hidden if the subject does not include any external applications and does not have information included in the
Important Info
section.

input: Within Canvas Elementary Homeroom, which elements show announcements, subjects, dates, weekly tasks, resources, and grades?
expected_output:
Within the Canvas for Elementary Homeroom, you’ll see:

1. Homeroom announcements [1]  
2. Active subjects [2]  
3. Important dates [3]  
4. This week’s tasks and events [4]  
5. Resources [5]  
6. Subject grades [6] (if your instructor has made them available)
context:
Document Title: What is Canvas for Elementary

What is Canvas for Elementary?
Canvas for Elementary is a Canvas setting that displays a simplified interface and experience designed for young learners.
The Canvas for Elementary setting can be enabled at a school's account or sub-account level. When enabled, the Canvas for Elementary interface displays to all users enrolled in at least one active subject within the account or sub-account.
When enabled, users enrolled in Canvas for Elementary subjects can view a
homeroom
which displays the user's subjects and information or resources that apply to all of their subjects. Within an individual
subject
, a user can view upcoming tasks and information or resources that apply to that subject.
What is the Homeroom?
The Homeroom is a course designated by an instructor to act as a home base in which students can view information or resources pertaining to all of their subjects.
Within the homeroom, users can view homeroom announcements [1], their active subjects [2], and
important dates
[3].
They can also view a
schedule of this week's tasks and events
[4], resources [5], and, if made available by the instructor, subject grades [6].
Learn more about the Homeroom.
What is a subject?
A subject is a course in which holds information pertaining to one topic or subject.
Within a subject, users can view subject-specific announcements [1] and, if added by the instructor, the subject home page [2].
Subject users can also view modules [3],
this week's tasks and events
[4], and resources [5].
If made available by the instructor, users can also view subject grades [6] and groups [7].
Learn more about subjects.
Notes:
The Modules, Resources, and Groups tabs may not display if they're not being used in the subject.
Subject tabs can also be hidden by the instructor.

input: In my Canvas course, the Modules, Resources, and Groups tabs are hidden. How can an instructor restore them?
expected_output:
1. As an instructor, go to your course and click Settings in the course navigation.  
2. Select the Navigation tab.  
3. In the “Hidden” list, locate Modules, Resources, and Groups.  
4. Drag each item up into the “Visible” list (or click the three-dot icon next to each and choose Enable).  
5. Scroll down and click Save to restore those tabs.

input: With the Homeroom feature enabled, how can instructors, students, and observers view announcements in the dropdown when the tabs are hidden?
expected_output:
Instructors and Students  
1. In Global Navigation, click Courses and choose Homeroom.  
2. In the Homeroom header, click the course-name dropdown arrow.  
3. Select Announcements from the menu.  

Observers  
1. In Global Navigation, use the Observer dropdown to pick a student.  
2. Follow steps 1–3 above to access that student’s Homeroom announcements.
context:
Document Title: What is the Homeroom in Canvas for Elementary

What is the Homeroom in Canvas for Elementary?
This lesson applies to users at institutions that have enabled the Canvas for Elementary user interface.
The Homeroom is a dashboard in which users access their active subjects and view information or resources that apply to all of their subjects.
When a course is enabled as the Homeroom, users can also view Homeroom announcements and access resources that have been added to the Homeroom course.
Instructor View
In the Homeroom, instructors can
view and manage homeroom announcements
[1], access their published and unpublished subjects [2],
add a new subject
[3], and view important dates [4].
Instructors can also view a schedule preview [5], access grades [6], view and manage Homeroom course resources [7], and view their To Do list [8].
Learn more about the Homeroom.
Note:
A course must be
enabled as the Homeroom course
to manage homeroom announcements and information in the Homeroom Resources tab.
Student View
In the Homeroom, students can view homeroom announcements [1], active and published subjects in which they're enrolled [2], and
important dates
[3].
Students can also
view the current week's schedule for all their subjects
[5],
access grades
[6], and view Homeroom resources [7].
Learn more about the Homeroom.
Note:
If a Homeroom navigation tab does not display, the instructor may have hidden the tab.
Observer View
Observers with multiple students can choose which student's Homeroom they'd like to view using the Observer drop-down menu [1].
Observers can view the student's
homeroom announcements
[2], active and published subjects in which they're enrolled [3], and the student's
important dates
[4].
They can
view the current week's schedule
[5]. If made available by the instructor, observers can also
access their student's grades
[6] and view Homeroom resources [7].
Learn more about the Homeroom.
Note:
If a Homeroom navigation tab does not display, the instructor may have hidden the tab.

input: How does enabling the Homeroom course and hiding navigation tabs as an instructor affect which course navigation tabs students can see?
expected_output:
1. Enable the course as the Homeroom (Course Settings → select Homeroom course)  
   - This makes the Homeroom dashboard available to users, adding tabs for Announcements, Subjects, Important Dates, Schedule Preview, Grades, Resources, and To Do.  

2. Hide navigation tabs (Course Settings → Navigation → drag unwanted tabs to the hidden list → Save)  
   - Any tab you hide here—even Homeroom-specific tabs—will no longer appear for students or observers.  

Result: Students only see the Homeroom navigation tabs you have left visible. If you hide a tab, it’s removed from their view; if you don’t enable a course as Homeroom, they cannot access Homeroom announcements or resources.

input: In the Canvas Elementary student view, where can I find Modules and the Weekly Schedule?
expected_output:
1. Log in to Canvas for Elementary and open your subject.  
2. In the student subject navigation bar, click Modules (tab 3) to view all your modules.  
3. Click Weekly Schedule (tab 4) to see your week’s events and assignments.  
Note: If you don’t see these tabs, your instructor may have hidden or rearranged them.
context:
Document Title: What is a subject in Canvas for Elementary

What is a subject in Canvas for Elementary?
This lesson applies to users at institutions that have enabled the Canvas for Elementary user interface
.
A subject is a Canvas course displayed in the Canvas for Elementary interface, which houses assignments and events pertaining to a topic.
Instructor View
In a subject, instructors can manage subject content [1], view the subject as a student [2],
manage subject announcements
[3], and view the
subject home page
[4].
Instructors can also view subject modules [5], the schedule preview [6], grades [7], subject resources [8], and subject groups [9].
Learn more about navigating a subject.
Notes:
If your subject does not use modules, groups, or resources, the Modules, Groups, or Resources tabs may not display.
You can also choose to
hide or rearrange subject navigation tabs
.
Student View
In a subject, students can view subject announcements [1], the subject home page [2], modules [3],
the subject's weekly schedule
[4], their
subject grades
[5], resources [6], and subject groups [7].
Learn more about navigating a subject.
Notes:
If your subject does not use modules, groups, or resources, the Modules, Groups, or Resources tabs may not display.
Your instructor can also choose to hide or rearrange subject navigation tabs.
Observer View
If an observer has more than one student in the same subject, they can select which student's information to view in the
Observing
drop-down menu [1].
Observers can view their student's subject home page [2], modules [3], the
subject's weekly schedule
[4], their
student's subject grades
[5], resources [6], and subject groups [7].
Learn more about navigating a subject.
Notes:
If your subject does not use modules, groups, or resources, the Modules, Groups, or Resources tabs may not display.
Your student's instructor can also choose to hide or rearrange subject navigation tabs.

input: How can instructors access and reorder or hide the subject navigation tabs (Modules, Groups, Resources) in Canvas Elementary?
expected_output:
1. In your Canvas for Elementary subject, click Settings in the subject navigation sidebar.  
2. Select the Navigation tab at the top of the Settings page.  
3. To reorder tabs, drag Modules, Groups, or Resources to your preferred position in the Visible section.  
4. To hide a tab, drag it down into the Drag items here to hide area.  
5. Click Save at the bottom to apply your changes.

input: In Canvas Elementary schedules, how do the Prev/Next buttons, item names, checkboxes, and completed/missing dropdowns work?
expected_output:
Here’s how each control works in both Homeroom and Subject schedules in Canvas Elementary:

1. Navigate Weeks with Prev/Next  
   • Click “Previous” or “Next” to move to last week’s or upcoming week’s tasks.  

2. View Item Details via Item Name  
   • Click any assignment, quiz, discussion, or event title to open its details page.  

3. Complete Items with Checkboxes  
   • Online submissions mark themselves complete automatically.  
   • For non-submission tasks, click the checkbox next to the item to mark it done.  

4. Show Completed Items  
   • Open the “Show completed item” dropdown to display or hide tasks you’ve already finished.  

5. Show Missing Items  
   • Open the “Show missing items” dropdown to list past due tasks you haven’t completed yet.
context:
Document Title: What is the Schedule in Canvas for Elementary

What is the Schedule in Canvas for Elementary?
This lesson applies to users at institutions that have enabled the Canvas for Elementary user interface.
This lesson shows you what is the Schedule in Canvas for Elementary. If your course appears differently than this lesson, follow the guide on
what is the scheduler
in Classic Canvas.
The Schedule allows you to view assignments, discussions, quizzes, and events by week. The homeroom schedule displays weekly tasks for all of your subjects. A subject schedule displays weekly tasks for that subject.
Notes:
If the Schedule tab does not display in your homeroom or subject, it has been hidden by the instructor.
Instructors cannot view the the Schedule for their Homeroom or subjects.
View Homeroom Schedule
In the
Homeroom Schedule
tab [1], you can view this week's tasks for all of your subjects.
To view previous or future week schedules, use the
Previous
or
Next
buttons [2].
You can view information for an item such as the item's subject, title, due or To Do date, instructor feedback, and meeting links [3].
To view the item's details, click the item name [4].
When an online assignment is submitted, the item is automatically marked as completed. You can manually mark non-submission items as complete by clicking the item's checkbox [5]. To view completed assignments, click the
Show completed item
dropdown [6].
To view past tasks you have not completed, click the
Show missing items
dropdown [7].
View Subject Schedule
In a subject's
Schedule
tab [1], you can view this week's tasks for the subject.
To view previous or future week schedules, use the
Previous
or
Next
buttons [2].
You can view information for an item such as the item's title, due or To Do date, instructor feedback, and meeting links [3].
To view the item's details, click the item name [4].
When an online assignment is submitted, the item is automatically marked as completed. You can manually mark non-submission items as complete by clicking the item's checkbox [5]. To view completed assignments, click the
Show completed item
dropdown [6].
To view past tasks you have not completed, click the
Show missing items
dropdown [7].

input: How can I access and use the Homeroom Schedule for weekly Canvas Elementary assignments when the Schedule subject is hidden?
expected_output:
1. If you don’t see the Homeroom Schedule tab in your Canvas for Elementary navigation, ask your instructor to unhide it in the course settings.  
2. Once visible, click Homeroom Schedule to open this week’s tasks across all subjects.  
3. Use the Previous and Next buttons to move between weeks.  
4. Click any item name to view details (subject, due/To Do date, feedback, meeting links).  
5. Online assignments auto-mark complete on submission. For other tasks, click the checkbox to mark complete.  
6. Use the Show completed items dropdown to review finished work and Show missing items to catch up on past tasks.

What are Important Dates in Canvas for Elementary?
This lesson applies to users at institutions that have enabled the Canvas for Elementary user interface.
Assignments, discussions, quizzes, and events that the instructor has marked as important displays in the Important Dates sidebar in the Homeroom.
View Important Dates
In the
Homeroom
[1], you can view assignments, discussions, quizzes, and events that the subject instructor has marked as important in the
Important Dates
sidebar [2].
Items in the Important Dates sidebar are organized by the associated due date or event date [3].

input: How are entries in the Homeroom IDs section sorted by due date or event date, how are their icons and subject names displayed, and how can I open them?
